Praefatio.	 Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	 After I have completed for you, O Sons, this book which is the last in medicine with its complement, and reached the end of it through its expositions and declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise which is a part of practice, that is, surgery by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	 Since the practice by hand is fallen in our region and our time, it has been entirely neglected; perhaps its science has perished, and its trace has been cut off, and nothing remains of it except small descriptions in the books of the ancients, which hands have changed: and error and confusion happened to them until their intentions were closed, and their power was withdrawn. It seemed to me that I should revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise on it according to the way of position, declaration, and abbreviation; and that I should come with forms of cautery instruments and other tools of work: as is done by the addition of declaration, and by hastening what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	 The reason why a good practitioner of it with his hand is not found in this our time is that the art of medicine is long, and its author must be trained beforehand in the science of anatomy, as Galen has described, until he knows the supports of members, and their forms, and their conjunction, and separation, and has knowledge of bones, and nerves, and muscles, and their number, and their exit, and of pulsating and quiet veins, and the exits of them.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	 And because of this, Hippocrates said: "A name with a name is much, and with work it is little, especially in the art of hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	 But we have already spoken about that at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	 Because the one who is not knowledgeable about what we have said regarding anatomy does not evacuate himself, so that he might fall into error, by which men are killed: just as I have seen many of those who profess to be experts in this science and boast about it without knowledge and without experimentation.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	 What happened was that I saw a foolish doctor cut into a scrofulous swelling on a woman's neck and he cut some of the arteries in the neck, so blood flowed from the woman until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	 And I saw another doctor who dared to extract a stone from an old man, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	 So he came to him and extracted it along with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	 Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	 And indeed I was already called to extract it, and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	 And I saw another doctor who was receiving a payment from a certain Duke of our land on account of his medicine; and it happened to a black eunuch who was with him that he broke his leg near the ankle. And the doctor hurried with his ignorance and bound the fracture over the wound with bandages and strong straps, and did not leave the wound room for breathing.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	 Then he released him according to his own desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	 Afterwards he sent him away for some days and ordered him not to loosen the bandage; and it stayed like that until his leg became swollen, and also his foot, and it reached a fatal end.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	 So I was called to him, and I hurried to loosen the bandage; and there followed peace, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	 Nevertheless, corruption had already taken hold in the limb; and I could not stop it.  /> I have translated the text as requested, without any notes or changes to all caps. If you need any further assistance, please let me know.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	 Therefore, cease walking on the affected limb until it heals.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	 And I saw another physician who punctured a cancerous abscess; and after several days it became an ulcer, until its evil increased greatly with the master himself.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	 That is, because when it is pure cancer from black bile, then one should not approach it with iron at all, unless it is in a limb that can tolerate it, so that its entirety may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	 And because of that, O my sons, it is necessary for you to know that the surgical procedure is divided into two parts: namely, the procedure associated with health; and the procedure which carries danger in many conditions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	 And I have already pointed out in every place in this book where an operation occurs that is accompanied by fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	 Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of that and to avoid it, so that the foolish do not find a way to speak and bring shame.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	 Therefore, receive the measure with diligence and prudence, and treat your patients with gentleness and firmness, and use the better path that leads through God's grace to health and praiseworthy success; and abandon terrible diseases of difficult cure; and lift up your spirits from what makes you afraid, so that hesitation may not come upon you in your faith and advantage.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	 For it is more becoming to your glory, and more exalted in this world, and finally, it is more profitable for you.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	 For Galen has already said in some of his warnings.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	 Do not treat evil diseases, lest you be called an evil physician.  />
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	 But now I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	 Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	 On Cautery with Fire and Cautery with Sharp Medicine, arranged and organized from head to foot, and on the shapes of the instruments and tools for cautery, and on everything necessary for the procedure.
Capitulum secundum.	 Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	 About the cutting and piercing, bloodletting and cupping, wounds, extraction of arrows and similar things: and all the chapters are arranged according to the forms of the instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	 Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	 About restoration and dislocation, and the cure of twisting, and similar things: a chapter arranged from head to toe and according to the forms of the instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	 To God alone be the glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	 The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	 Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	 ¶ About Help and Harm of Cautery: and in which tempers it is suitable, and at what time: and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	 Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	 But before remembering its use, it is necessary to say the quality of its benefit and harm, and in which temperament it is given.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	 I say therefore that the discourse on the quality of the benefit of cautery and its harm is a lengthy and subtle scientific discourse, and an obscure secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	 Even many wise men have spoken about it and differed on the subject, and for me a little of their speech is enough, fearing prolongation. xspace
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	 I say therefore that cautery benefits every temperament, which is with matter and without matter, except for two temperaments which are the hot temperament without matter and the dry temperament without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	 But in the temperament which is hot and dry with matter they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	 For some said that cautery is beneficial in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	 And others said the opposite of this, namely that cautery is not suitable for an illness caused by heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat, and it is inappropriate to heal a hot and dry illness with something hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	 And he who speaks against it says: that cautery provides a benefit in every warm and dry illness that occurs in human bodies, for when you compare the body of a human and its humors to the composition of fire, you find the body of a man to be cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	 And I indeed say through his words: because experience has already revealed this to me many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	 But it is not right that anyone come to this, except one who has already been proven and trained in the last chapter of cautery exercise, and knows the diversity of human complexions, and the nature of illnesses within themselves, and their causes, and their symptoms, and their duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	 But concerning other complexions, there is no fear over you; especially in cold and moist illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	 For all doctors have agreed upon them; and they did not disagree on the benefit of cautery for them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	 And know, my children, that from the secret of treatment with cautery with fire and its goodness is greater than cautery with burning medicine; for fire is simple, whose action does not reach except to the member that is being cauterized; and it does not harm another member connected with it, except with a small injury.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	 But the action of burning medicine reaches that which is distant from the members; and perhaps it causes an illness of difficult healing in the member, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	 But fire, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do that, except if it is too much. ››
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	 Indeed, that has become clear to us through experience, due to the length of our service and study with this art, and our adherence to the truth of things; and because of that, I am free from the length of discourse.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	 And if it were not permitted to my book, I would present to you the secret hidden in fire and the nature of its operation in expelling bodies, which by means of philosophical demonstrative speech, would cure you of your illnesses.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	 And know that they disagree on the time when it is suitable to perform a cautery, and they prefer the vernal season.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	 And I say that a cautery is suitable at any time; because the harm which occurs due to the season is overwhelmed by the benefit which is drawn from the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	 And especially if the cautery is for necessary, strong, and urgent pains which do not allow delay; because one fears from them that a greater harm may occur than a slight injury caused by the season.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	 And do not let this thought enter your minds, O sons, that only the common and foolish physicians think thus: namely, that the illness which is cured by cautery does not always return; and they put forward this consequence, but it is not as they suppose: because cautery is not anything other than a medicine which alters the complexion and dries up the humors which are the causes of the pains.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	 Nevertheless, cautery surpasses medicine in the speed of its action and the strength of its operation and the intensity of its dominion; and it is possible for the illness to return at some time according to the complexion of the patient and the location of his illness and its strength; and what is prepared in his body from an accumulation of superfluous humors in him; and what comes to him in acquiring them from foods and similar causes, unless the illness for which cautery is administered occurs.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	 A subtle illness in a member with few superfluities and moistures, such as tooth cautery for pain and similar cases, it is possible that the pain will not return there.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	 "But that happens rarely.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	 "But the common belief is again that the cautery is the last resort of medicine; this is the correct view, not as they themselves intend it: because they believe that there is no treatment that can be compared to medicine, nor to anything else after the cessation of the cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	 "The truth is contrary to that belief and the intent behind it, namely that cautery is the last resort of medicine; it is not, except when we apply methods of treatment for some ailments and they do not work, then we finally apply cautery and it works. Then it follows that cautery is the last resort of treatment, not in the sense that the common people and many foolish doctors understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	 "The ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron, and they only said this because of the evenness of gold and its high quality; and they said that the site of the cautery does not form pus.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	 "But this is not absolutely true, for I have already tested it and found that it does not do so in certain bodies without other factors.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	 "And cautery with gold itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	 "However, when you apply the cautery fire made of gold into the fire, it does not indicate to you how much heat is generated according to your will because of the redness of gold; and when it becomes very hot, if you add more fire to it, it melts in the fire and turns into plates.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	 "Therefore, the artisan falls short due to that; and because of it, cautery with iron is quicker and more convenient among us for the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	 "And indeed I have already arranged this chapter on cautery according to sections, and I have arranged them from head to foot; so that those who seek something specific may find it more easily.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	 On how to cauterize the head at the hairline.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	 This cauterization serves to control moisture and cold over the brain: these two are causes of catarrh and an excess of humors flowing from the head to the eyes and ears, as well as excessive sleep, toothache, and sore throat. And universally, every illness that occurs from cold, such as paralysis, catarrh, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	 The method of cauterization is as follows: advise the patient to first cleanse the head with a cleansing medicine for three or four nights, according to the strength, age, and habit of the patient.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	 Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	 Then have him sit before you facing eastward, placing his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	 Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	 Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with an ink pen.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	 Then heat the cautery with olive oil. This is its form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	 Then place it on the marked spot with an ink pen, and gradually lower your hand until you turn it over.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	 Then quickly lift your hand and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	 If you see that the bone is already exposed to the size of a lentil or cumin seed, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	 And if not, repeat with the same iron or another if it cools down, until you see the bones I mentioned to you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then take some salt, dissolve it in water, and wet a piece of cotton with it, then place it on the spot, and leave it there for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	 Then place a cloth soaked in butter over it, and leave it there until the fire scab is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	 Then care for it with tetraphylax ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	 They have already said that the more the wound remains open, the more pus it emits: therefore it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	 And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized to the bone: and the cautery should be held until something of the thickness of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	 Then after that which has been burnt from the bone, it should be scraped, then cleaned out.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	 And others say that it is necessary to reach the very end with the cautery until it imprints on the bone the mark of the instrument known as kirate, or the small alphabetical device which women use. They believe that from this place the vapors of the head are expelled and the wound should be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	 Then it should be cleaned out until it heals.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	 To me, however, these two kinds of cautery do not seem altogether suitable except for certain people according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	 And to leave it is, in my opinion, better with regard to the patient's health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	 For the head is weakened by the dissolution of its natural continuity, as we have shown for other members; and especially when the head of a sick person is naturally weak. The first kind of cautery seems to me more wholesome and better, and I use it. Therefore, operate with it in health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing the head for pain throughout the entire head.
Caput III.	 Chapter 3.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	 When a chronic pain occurs throughout the entire head and is prolonged in the patient, using leeches, cupping, purgatives, oils, and enemas.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	 And especially if it has already been cauterized with one of the irons that we mentioned, and nothing else benefits it: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	 For if the head of the patient is of strong constitution and not weak, and it finds intense cold: then cauterize with another iron beneath that one.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	 Then cauterize the same over every horn of his head with an iron, so that it does not penetrate the skin, and a quantity of bone is exposed, as we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	 And cauterize him with one iron in the occiput of his head, in a place called the vessel, and it is the place where the windpipe is placed. And lift up your hand in this, and you will not expose bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	 For the patient will find intense pain from that, and it is different from the pain of all other head cauteries.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	 And I call this cautery "in its place": and it ought to be a finer iron than that with which the horns of the head and the back of the head are cauterized, compared to the iron with which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	 § On the manner of cauterizing in hemicrania, both with burning medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	 When pain and swelling occur in any part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and the head is evacuated with purifying medicines, and the rest of the treatment, as I said in the divisions of diseases, does not help entirely: then cauterization in it is according to two methods: either cauterization with a sharp burning medicine: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	 But cauterization with a sharp burning medicine is done as follows: take one tooth of garlic, and peel it, and cut off its ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	 Then cut the place of pain with a wide phlebotomy needle until there is a space under the skin where the tooth can be held.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then insert it under the skin until it is hidden; then bind over it with a suitable bandage, and leave it for fifteen hours; then remove it, and extract the garlic clove, and leave the wound open for two or three days; then place a cotton ball soaked in butter over it until pus forms in the area; then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	 And if you wish to make that with some burning medicines, which I have written about in the twelfth chapter on Burning Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	 The cauterization of it with iron is done in this way:
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	 Cautery Iron, the shape of which is this:
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	 And it is called "nail-shaped" because the shape of its head is like that of a nail, which has some curvature, and in the middle of it there is a small projection.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	 Then place it on the spot and hold your hand steady; and turn the iron slowly but quickly; and let the quantity that is burned be half the thickness of the skin.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And raise your hand so that the artery below is not burned and a flow of blood occurs.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then soak a cotton ball in salt water and place it on the spot and leave it for three days; then place a cotton ball with butter; afterwards, treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	 And if you wish, cauterize this semi-skull with the point of a second scalpel.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	 And be careful not to cut the artery in this semi-skull, which is not old.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	 On the method of cauterizing an old semi-skull.
Caput V.	 Chapter Five
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	 When treating hemicrania, along with what we have said in the preceding treatment and in the division of diseases, if the treatment does not help: you see from the disease that what has been said about cautery first with medicine or with cautery using fire is not enough. Then it is necessary to burn a surgical cautery until it whitens after marking the location of pain with a line whose length is half a finger or thereabouts. And place your hand in its place, and tighten it until you cut the artery, and reach the mouth.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	 However, it is necessary for you to be careful not to burn the side or the nerve that moves the jaw during chewing, so that a spasm does not occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	 And take care and caution against bleeding from the cut artery.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	 For its incision is dangerous, especially for one who does not know how to do it and is not diligent or experienced, and he abandons the procedure first of all.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	 And I will make amends by recalling the method to control bleeding that occurs from the artery, in its proper place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 But if you see from the disease that this cautery is not sufficient and you see that the patient's body can withstand cautery in the middle of the head, as we have described, cure the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	 And if you wish, administer the cautery that we have mentioned in the chapter on extracting an artery with a two-bladed cautery.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	 For this cauterization is better and more beneficial.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	 § On the method of cauterizing ear pain. ¶
Caput VI.	 Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	 When ear pain occurs due to cold and is treated with solutions and other treatments as we have said in the division, and the pain does not go away, then burn a cautery called "Point," whose form is this:
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	 Then make marks around it after its burning on the whole circumference of the ear; or around both if the pain is simultaneous in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	 And draw back the Cautery from the root of the ear after you have marked the places with Encaut; and let the quantity of the Cautery be ten pricks in each ear, and thus.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	 Then care for the places until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	 ¶ On the manner of Cautery in Torture.
Caput VII.	 Chapter Seven.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	 Torture which is treated with Cautery is only from species that occur due to Phlegm, as we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	 And avoid Cautery for the species which occurs from dryness and nerve spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	 When you treat this species of Torture with emetics, purgatives, and gargles, and your treatment is not effective, then it is necessary to Cauterize the sick person with three Cauteries: one at the root of the ear, a second a little lower than its tympanum, and a third at the junction of the two lips. 
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	 And place your Cautery opposite to the affected side.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	 Because softening occurs only in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	 And the method of Cautery is that you should Cauterize it directly at the tip of the upper part of the ear, a little under the horn of the head; and another in the tympanum, whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	 And withdraw your hand with the Cautery until a quantity equal to half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	 And this is the method of Cautery and it is a species from the knife whose shape has been described before; however, it is not very subtle, as you see: and the knife should be slightly thicker than necessary.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	 Then care for the places with what preceded, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	 Of the manner of cauterizing in an old apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter 8
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	 When the apoplexy becomes old and you have treated it with what we said, and your treatment does not help, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on each corner of his head, and a cautery in the middle of the head, as we said, and a cautery on the back of the head, according to what preceded: and the manner of cauterizing should be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	 Also he is cauterized with a cautery on the mouth of the stomach: and this is more final.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then let him be treated with what preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	 Of the manner of cauterizing in oblivion.
Caput IX.	 Chapter 9
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	 It is necessary that in the first place they give the sick man large doses of hyena and pills that purify the brain. ︎
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	 Then shave the head of the sick man entirely, and place on his nape an emplaster made from mustard, as described in the treatise on emplasters: and apply it several times. ︎ ︎
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	 For this itself is the manner of cautery: and do it according to the same order that I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	 If therefore he is healed by that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	 If not, then make for him three cauteries on the back of his head, which should descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye: and put between each cautery the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then care for the cauteries with what preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	 If however you wish to add to it, and the patient can bear it: then make a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	 If you wish to add to it: then cauterize him on both corners. ︎ ︎
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	 Then care for him until he is healed; and let the cautery be oiled according to the aforementioned shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	 The method of cauterizing in paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	 Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	 It is necessary that you proceed with the cleansing of the head using honey and as we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	 Then shave the head of the patient; afterwards cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with a cautery over each horn of the head, and with a cautery over its posterior, and three times over the nape of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	 But if you need to soften the body with more of those remedies, and the patient is strong enough, and the disease is severe; then cauterize him with four cauteries over the nape of the neck, and the last one until it burns a lot from his skin, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	 Then care for him until he is healed; and thus oil the cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	 The method of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	 Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 An epileptic is not cauterized except one whose epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you first cleanse his brain with honey and the other treatment which we have said in the division; when the patient is large or strong in taking medicine. ‌
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	 But if he is a child who does not tolerate medicine, then give him gargle and brain-cleansing chews for many days beforehand with the improvement of foods.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	 Then shave his head; afterwards cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of the head, as it was said before in the method; and with another cautery on his nape, and over each horn of his head with a cautery. ‌ ‌
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	 But if the patient is strong and can tolerate it, then cauterize him with the cauteries which I mentioned for the one having paralysis, and soften his body over the nape of the neck and the nape of the back; and let the cautery be oiled according to the aforementioned method. ‌ ‌ ‌
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	 If however the patient is a child, then place a fine cautery in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	 § On how to cauterize in cases of melancholy.
Caput XII.	 Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 When the cause of melancholy is due to corrupt humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize with the same cauteries we mentioned for those with paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	 And if the cause of melancholy is due to superfluous humors tending towards black bile, and the body of the patient is moist, then give him a drink that will cleanse his brain, as was previously mentioned in the division. Then shave the head of the patient, and afterwards make a neatly shaped torus from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	 Then place it in the middle of the head, and let the patient sit upright, held on all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	 Then presently apply an ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	 And it is best made from old mutton fat. xspace
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	 And warm the ointment over a moderate fire, so that when a finger is inserted into it, it will be comfortable to the touch.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	 Then evacuate it onto the middle of his head in a circle, and leave it until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	 Do this for the patient once every week, along with his other good dietary practices, until he is cured. xspace 3
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	 Or if you wish, you can cauterize him by making many small punctures on it, except that you should hold the hand with the cautery; indeed, let it be smelling.  xspace 1 3
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	 For this type of cautery moistens the brain with quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	 Then place over it a piece of cloth soaked in butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	 § On how to cauterize when water flows into the eye.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	 When the beginning of water in the eye is indicated to you by the signs that I mentioned in the division, then begin and give the patient a drink that will cleanse his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	 And keep him from all moistures, and have him sit in a bath while fasting for several days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	 Then order him to shave his head, and cauterize him in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	 Then cauterize him on both temples with two cauteries, if there is an attempt at water descending into both eyes together; or from one side only, if there is an attempt at water descending into one eye only; and cut out with the cautery all the veins and arteries that are under the skin. And let the cauteries be long in the breadth of the temples. And take care to avoid blood flow.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	 If you see anything from him, then cut it out immediately with whatever medicine is possible. And I come with wisdom, which is in the drawing out of the arteries and their cutting off, and care to avoid blood flow.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	 And when he is cauterized on the neck, under the two bones, with two cauteries fully extended.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	 On the method of cauterizing old tears.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter 14.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	 When the tears of the eyes are chronic and persistent, lying over the veins and arteries that are on the exterior surface of the head, it is verified that this is from cold and phlegmatic superfluities. Then cauterize with the same cautery as I have described for water descending into the eyes, in the middle of the head, and two cauteries on both temples, and two cauteries on the neck under the two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	 And if you need an additional measure, then cauterize him on every side of the eye, on the outer edge of the eyebrow with a small cautery. ️
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	 On the method of cauterizing bad smell from the nose.
Caput XV.	 Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	 When you are treating this, with what we have said concerning division, and the treatment is not helpful: then hasten and give him weak broth to drink for three nights; then shave his head, and cauterize him with a medium-sized cautery, with an olive cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	 Then cauterize it with two cautery irons, over the two eyebrows under the hair a little.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	 And beware of the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	 And this is the shape of the clavicle cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	 § On the method of cauterizing for softening the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	 When the eyelid of the eye is softened by illness or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery iron, using this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	 And if you wish, cauterize it slightly over the two eyebrows with two cautery irons in every part, and let them be distant from the two temples; and let the length of each cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow; and do not complete your hand with the cautery, rather according to the amount that the third eyelid is burnt. 
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	 And this is the shape of the cautery according to this method of the lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	 § On the method of cauterizing the eyelid when the lashes are turned inward, pricking the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	 The cautery for this is done in two ways: either with a hot cautery, or with a cautery that has been prepared with burning medicine.    
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 In the case of the hot cautery, before that, instruct the patient to let his lashes grow, if he is one who cleans them, until they are lengthened and evened out.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	 But if they prick him at their roots, then bind his eyes with a ribbon so that they do not move until they grow out.       
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	 So when they grow out and are evened, then place the patient's head in your lap; then mark the eyelid of his eye with encaustic, making a mark that is shaped like a myrtle leaf; and let the beginning of the mark be near the lashes.       
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	 Then apply the soaked linen cloth on egg white or psyllium mucilage over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then heat the cautery iron, which looks like this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	 Then cauterize gradually on the area you have marked in many sessions until the surface of the skin, which is shaped like a myrtle leaf, becomes completely visible.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	 And the sign of health for your work is this: if you see the eyelid contracting and the hairs around the eye rising at the point where it was pierced.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Raise your hand then, and let him rest for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	 Then place a linen cloth with butter over it until the scab is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with an ointment until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	 But if any hair returns after an hour and the eyelid softens, then repeat the cautery on that spot as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	 But if the hairs are below, then cauterize them until they lift to their natural place and are equal so that the hairs do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	 On how to cauterize with a burning medicine in this case.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter Eighteen
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 Instruct the patient to let the hairs grow out and become equal.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	 Make the shape of a myrtle leaf from paper cloth.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	 Then take known soap and unwetted lime, one ounce each or thereabouts, then grind them together well, and make this mixture quickly so that it does not cool down.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	 Then spread this mixture over the paper leaf shape you made and place it on the eyelid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	 And place a linen cloth soaked in egg white under the eye, and let the patient's head rest on your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	 And place your index finger on the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	 You shall move it as often as the patient feels the biting of the medicine, for its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	 While he continues to feel the biting of this medicine, then release the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	 When the biting ceases, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	 And see then, if you see the eyelid raised, as it is raised when contracted by fire or by cutting, it is good. And if not, then repeat on that same place from the medicine in the area where the medicine does not press and does not darken, until your treatment becomes equal and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	 Then apply to it kohl with butter, until the skin of the burn is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with diaphanic ointment or another, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	 And it is necessary for you during the treatment that you carefully watch so that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If the eyelid becomes soft after a few days and something bothers the eye from the hairs, then repeat the medicine on that place of the eyelid which is becoming soft specifically, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	 And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	 And know that the eyes of men differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	 Therefore, according to this, let your consideration be; and the way of righteousness is not hidden from him who studies this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	 ¶ On how to cauterize the lacrimal duct.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	 When you treat the fistula with what we have said about the divisions of diseases and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary that you cauterize it in this way.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	 Tell the patient to place his head in your lap, and let the assistant hold the patient's head between his hands so that it does not move or shake with the patient's head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then place a cautery tool dipped in egg white or slippery elm mucilage on the eye: then use a heated iron instrument shaped like this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	 Let the cautery be hollow, like a reed pen, with one end closed, and if you wish for it to reach the other end, or if you wish for it to go upwards, then proceed thus.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	 However, this hollow instrument is better suited for your task.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	 Then squeeze the abscess if it is open, and extract the pus from it, and cauterize it; and if it is not open, then open it, and extract its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	 Then place a very hot cautery on it.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	 And hold your hand with the cautery near the eye, towards the nose, so that your hand does not wander or disturb the patient; and place the cautery on the eyeball and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	 If you reach the beginning of your incision up to the mouth, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery once or twice, if needed; and leave it alone for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	 Then apply an ointment with butter, and treat the wound with a drying ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	 But if forty days have passed and it does not heal, then apply a sharp corrosive medicine to it until the opening is revealed; and scrape it according to its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	 And there is another method of cauterizing an abscess that some have said first.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 Direct your attention to the site of the abscess and find it; then place a fine probe into its opening, that is, a fine cannula whose shape is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	 And pour into it a quantity of melted lead equal to a drachm, and hold your hand firmly with the reed, so that the patient does not move at all, lest the melted lead should reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	 And it is necessary to place on the patient's eye a compress soaked in egg white or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 For lead burns the site of the fistula and heals it with remarkable healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	 If the fistula is cured by what we have said from cautery and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	 And if not, then it is necessary to make an opening in the nose and bring the fistula into the course of the nose, according to its own proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	 On the method of cauterizing lip fissures.
Caput XX.	 Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	 Often there are fissures on the lip, which are called "Pili", especially in children's lips. 
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	 Therefore, when you treat these fissures with what we have said for the division of diseases, and treatment is not beneficial, then use a small scalpel-shaped cautery, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	 And let its cavity be as thin as a knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	 Then place the heated cautery quickly on the fissures themselves, until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with cerate until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	 On the method of cauterizing a mouth fistula.   
Caput XXI.	 Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	 When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum or palate or at the roots of the teeth: then pus is formed and it breaks open; afterwards it becomes chronic and pus runs out, and a fistula is formed. Then you treat the fistula itself, but if treatment does not benefit, then it is necessary to heat the cautery according to its size that fits in the fistula. 
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	 Then introduce the burning one into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand until the burning iron reaches the depth and the end of it; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	 Then take care of him afterwards with what we have said about aftercare until he is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	 If the pus is cut off and it heals, then it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	 And if not, then it is necessary to expose the place and remove the rotten bone according to how much of it is affected.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	 § On the method of cauterizing gums and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter 22
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 When the gum is softened due to moistures and the teeth are moved, and you have cared for it with medicines but they do not help; then put the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	 Then prepare a cautery of fire, the form of which will be described later, so that you place a cannula on the tooth: and quickly introduce the burning cautery into it; and hold your hand for a little while until the patient feels the heat of the fire has already reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	 And lift up your hand; then repeat the cautery several times according to what you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	 Then let the patient fill his mouth with salt water and hold it for one hour; and then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	 For the moved tooth will be strengthened, and the softened gum will be tightened, and the corrupted moisture will be dried out.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	 § On the method of cauterizing dental pain.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter 23
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	 When the toothache is due to cold, whether the cold is within it or a worm, and treatment with medicines does not help; then there are two ways of applying a cautery to it: either cautery with butter or cautery with fire. 》
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	 The cautery of it with butter is such that you take cow's butter and boil it in a little iron pan or in an earthenware pot. 》 》 》
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	 Then take cotton and wrap it around the end of the probe.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	 Then immerse it in boiled butter; and place it quickly on the aching tooth, and hold it there until it cools; then repeat this several times, until the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	 And if you wish, immerse wool or cotton in cold butter and place it on the aching tooth; then place a heated iron on top of it, until the heat reaches the depths of the tooth cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	 The cautery of this with fire is to direct towards a bronze tube or an iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	 And let there be something thick in its body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the patient's mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	 Then take a heated cautery whose shape will come, and place it on that tooth; and hold your hand until the cautery cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	 Do this several times, for the pain will be removed either on that same day or another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	 And it is necessary that after the impression of that cautery, the patient should fill his mouth with good butter and hold it for one hour; then he should spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	 And this is the shape of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	 Cauterize with whatever end you wish, according to what is possible; and this is the shape of the tube.  />
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	 ¶ On the manner of cautery for throat ailments.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	 When throat ailments are caused by phlegm and cold moistures, and do not respond to medicines for digestion, and you wish to hasten their digestion; then take a hollow heated cautery, whose shape is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	 Having two open ends, so that the smoke may exit from one end of the cautery; and place the heated cautery on the swelling once or twice if needed, until it reaches the depths of the swelling.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	 If the abscess is small: then place the cautery according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	 Then leave it for three days and place a compress soaked in butter over it until what the fire burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	 Then treat it with tooth powder until it heals in the shape of a cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	 § On the manner of cauterizing for hoarseness of voice and constriction of breath.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter 25
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	 When moistures prevail over the bronchial tube and especially when it is with a cold temperament, then it is necessary for the patient to be first evacuated with dissolving remedies.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	 Then cauterize it in the soft part at the root of the throat in a depressed place; and beware that you do not reach the throat with the cautery, nor the skin, except for a little bit of it.  />
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	 Then cauterize it with another cautery at the junction of the neck on its last vertebra, terminating it; and let the cautery be sharp according to the previously mentioned manner.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with what was said before until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	 § On the manner of cauterizing for lung diseases and coughs.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26  />  />
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	 When cough and lung disease are from cold moistures, and the patient has no fever or consumption, and the illness is not chronic; then cauterize with two cauteries above the collarbone in depressed, gentle, empty places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	 And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two breasts; and let the cautery be a cannula according to the previously mentioned shape.
