Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	 And if you wish to cauterize by pricking with the cautery called "Punctum," whose shape was mentioned previously for the pricking of ear pain; and let there be thirty or more such pricks.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with what has preceded, until he is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	 And now let there be a cautery with three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	 Why is he alleviated by that cauterization when you perform on him in one go three cauteries?
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	 ¶ On the manner of cauterizing for Tetanus, in the dislocation of the shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	 When the head is dislocated because of humidity and does not return to its place at the hour of its own returning from its dislocation until it becomes habitual for it, then it is dislocated by a slight movement that happens as we have already testified about it; then you should return the dislocation first. 》
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	 Then the patient is placed on his back or on the healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	 Then raise the skin that is inside the Tetanus toward the upper parts with your left hand fingers: and if the joint is dislocated inward.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	 Then take a cautery with two points.
Cuius forma est haec.	 Whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	 Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and you will see the figure of the cauterization with four points.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	 And sometimes the cauterization is done with a cautery having three points, so that the figure of the cauterization then has six points; and the points are according to the fineness of the silk thread.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	 And this is the form of the cautery with three points.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	 And sometimes one more is added to this manner, so that there are eight points.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	 Then place on the cautery crushed garlic with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	 Then make the patient remain still so that he does not move the limb at any time until it is strengthened.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	 And if the dislocation is upward and this rarely happens, then cauterize him on the shoulder with a nail-like cautery or by making many small punctures.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	 The joint is strengthened, and moisture is removed; and the sick person is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	 Of the way of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter 28.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	 When cold and excessive moisture occur in the stomach, until they separate it from its proper balance, and catarrhs increase towards it, and persistent treatment methods do not help: then the sick person must be turned onto their back, and stretch out their legs and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	 Then cauterize with three cauteries, one cautery beneath the breastbone the size of half a finger's breadth, and two cauteries lower on either side of it, until the shape of the cauteries becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	 And extend between each so that they do not join when they produce pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	 And let the depth of the cautery be twice the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	 And let the shape of the cauteries be like this without addition; and if you wish, cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach like this: and let the cautery used for this cautery be one in the shape of a circle like this.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	 And the stomach should be cauterized by pricking it with this cautery; and mark on the stomach a point according to the size that you wish with the cautery; then cauterize it with a pointed cautery; then treat it with the treatment that came before until it heals. xspace: 48000
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	 Of the way of cauterizing cold liver.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	 When pain occurs in the liver from cold and moisture, or from excessive flatulence, until it deviates from its natural balance by an excessive discharge, and the sick person is treated with what we have said, and it does not help him: then the sick person must be turned onto his neck, and mark with a cautery three cauteries like this figure, and this size below the hypochondria, where the human elbow reaches; and let the space between each cautery be according to the thickness of a finger: and let the cautery be straight according to the length of the body: and do not press your hand much with the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	 And let the amount that is burned be from the thickness of the skin, half its amount not added: and let the patient stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	 If, however, he is not standing, then let him lie down with legs extended and arms raised.
Haec est forma cauterii.	 This is the form of cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	 And it is possible for you to perform this cautery with a lancet-shaped cautery when you have skill and wisdom in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	 And be careful not to proceed too far in cauterization, so that the thickness of all the skin is burned, because then the whole body will be burned and it will reach the intestines; for the skin there is thin, know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	 On the Method of Cauterizing Liver Abscesses
Caput XXX.	 Chapter 30
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	 When an abscess occurs and you want to know whether it is in the liver or its membrane, then if it is in the liver itself, pain and heaviness come upon the patient without sharpness. But if it is in the liver's membrane, there is severe sharp pain along with the pain. And you will see that his doctors have been unable to cure him.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	 Therefore, let the patient lie on his back.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 Then mark the site of the abscess with a caustic; then heat the cautery that resembles a ray. 》
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	 And cauterize with it once, until the whole skin is burned and it reaches the spleen, until all the pus comes out; then treat him according to the treatment for abscesses, until he is cured.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	 And this type of cautery should not be used except by someone whose study in the art of medicine has been long, and through whose hands these diseases frequently pass with experience; then he may dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	 And to dismiss it, I have a better way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	 ¶ On the Method of Cauterizing in Pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter XXXI
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	 The ancients said that a hot iron with the roots of birthwort is used for cold pleurisy in this manner.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	 And it is that you take from the dried and long roots of birthwort one root that is longer than the others, and let its thickness be like a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	 Then immerse it in oil, and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	 Then cauterize with one cautery where the collarbone meets the clavicle, and with two small cauteries a little oblique towards the side under the chin.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	 And with two cauteries also between the fifth and sixth ribs, slightly oblique towards the back; and one cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	 And with three cauteries from behind: one between the two shoulder blades, and two cauteries on both sides of the chest, below the cautery that is between the two shoulder blades. 》
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	 And it is not necessary to press with your hand while cauterizing; rather, let there be a distinct smell of the skin burning.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	 And some of the ancients have said that there are men who use a cautery like a needle made from iron, and they heat it and insert it between the ribs until it reaches the abscess, and pus comes out; as we have said concerning the liver abscess.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	 But in this perforation with a cautery, there is fear that either the patient dies immediately, or a fistula occurs in that place which cannot be cured.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	 ¶ On the Method of Cauterizing the Spleen Chapter XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	 When you are treating spleen disease with what we have said in the division of diseases, and your treatment is not effective, then there are three ways to cauterize it, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	 One is that you should make three cauteries or four lines along the length of the spleen according to the figure of the liver's cauteries, whose image precedes this.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	 And let there be between each cautery a thickness equal to a finger or slightly more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	 And let the manner of cautery be the same as we said for the liver's cautery.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	 And do not press your hand with the cautery, and let the patient be on their back with their head raised.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	 And another manner of cautery is that you burn with a cautery having two holes, as we said in the chapter on shoulder dislocation: and lift the skin which is directly above the spleen, where the patient's left elbow reaches; and let your lifting be such that you lift the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	 Then introduce two very hot holes until with them you penetrate the skin from the other side; then withdraw the cautery. Thus four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	 And if you wish to cauterize with another cautery having three holes.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	 Then care for the cauteries after you have removed it, so that it may emit pus for many days; for this is more beneficial than any of the previous treatments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	 ¶ On the manner of cauterizing in hydrops.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter 33
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	 A cautery is not made in hydrops except on the proper parts of the abdomen.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	 When you treat a hydroptic patient with the methods of treatment that we have mentioned in the division, and the treatment does not benefit, then it is necessary to cauterize him with four cauteries around the navel, and one cautery on the stomach, and another on the liver, and another on the spleen, and two cauteries behind the back between the shoulders, and one directly over the chest, and another directly over the stomach; and let the depth of the cautery be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	 Then let the cautery remain open so that it may emit pus over a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	 And do not remove the patient from treatment after the cautery, for it is necessary that two aims be achieved: and healing will hasten to him with God's help.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	 However, the form of the cautery with which one cauterizes the stomach should be claviform; as was said before about its form. And the form of that with which one cauterizes the back should be olive-shaped, as was said before about its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	 § On the method of cauterizing the feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XXXIV
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	 When there is swelling in a hydrocephalus patient and the water turns yellow, it is necessary to cauterize on top of the foot, specifically in the interdigital space between the auricular and annular regions. Lift your hand with the cautery and do not twist it; then lift your hand and do not press it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	 For the yellow water will drain, and let the cautery be in this shape.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	 Then make two cauteries on each leg, and let the cautery be with the end of a lancet's tip; and let the cautery be according to the length of the leg, one below the knee and the other lower than that, about midway along the leg. And make two cauteries on each thigh. And leave the cautery open without treatment for a long time, so that some water may drain from it; then treat it with the rest as we have said. ‌
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	 § On the method of cauterizing for abdominal pain.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter XXXV ‌
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	 When the abdominal pain is due to cold and moisture, which weaken the retentive and digestive powers in the stomach and intestines; and it is treated with remedial methods but does not heal; and you see that the patient tolerates a generous cautery well, then cauterize him with a large cautery on his stomach, as was said previously about the method of stomach cautery using a circular cautery. And make four subtle cauteries around the navel, using a subtle claviform cautery; and one large cautery on the alca above the anus, or two cauteries. ‌ ‌
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	 And if you see excessive humidity and the patient endures it, then cauterize him with a cautery above the pubic region, and with a cautery in each thigh; and perhaps you should add two small cauteries on the abdomen near the navel.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	 For healing is effective, whose benefit does not fail.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	 ¶ About the way of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	 When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus, or one, and they are from thick, cold humors, or corrupt humidity, and are treated as we said in division, and the treatment is not beneficial: then cauterize with three cauteries on the lower back of the spine under a slight triangular incision, and with a cautery below the navel about two finger widths.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 And if you think that his stomach is chilled and his food is not digested, and you see his face swollen, then cauterize him on the abdomen with a large cautery, as previously described; and with a cautery on his liver, and another on his spleen, together with a clavicle cautery. And leave the cautery open for some time; then treat him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	 ¶ About the way of cauterizing athlete's foot after their removal.
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter XXXVII.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 When you cut off athlete's foot, then heat a cautery that resembles a ray of light.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	 Then introduce it while burning into the cut athlete's foot; and continue your hand until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which the blood flows; do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	 If therefore there are many athlete's feet, then cauterize each one with a cautery as we have narrated.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	 Then treat them with the ointment that suits them until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	 And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on the scar, it is more effective as a remedy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	 On how to cauterize an anal fistula.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	 When the patient does not respond to incision and the operation we have described in its place, and is frightened by it, perhaps he will be cured with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	 So when someone gets an anal fistula and it becomes chronic, pus runs from it and corrupt humors.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	 It is therefore more worthy to probe it with a fine probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	 Then ascertain its depth with the probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	 Then heat a cautery that is similar to a ray.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	 Then introduce yourself with the heated cautery into the fistula and as far as the probe reached. ︎
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And repeat the cautery on it until all those corrupt bodies are burnt up, once, or twice, or three times, according to your need.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	 And beware of burning a nerve if there is one there, or a large vein; or if the fistula extends to the bladder or the intestine, then beware of all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	 And do not do this unless the fistula is in a fleshy place and you think it does not penetrate.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	 Then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	 But if the place is sealed and materials are cut off from it, and it remains this way for a long time, then know that it has healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 And if materials are not cut off from it, then know that it is penetrating, or there is a corrupt opening at its depth, or something like that of which the reminder will come in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	 On how to cauterize kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	 Chapter XXXIX. ︎
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	 When there is pain in the kidneys from cold or gross flatulence and the patient's strength is diminished because of it, then you should cauterize him on the loin above the kidney with a fine cautery, as we have mentioned before.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	 And perhaps we will cauterize it a second time on that very same spot.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	 Why do three lines appear?
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	 Therefore, they will be more helpful in the end.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	 On the Method of Cauterizing the Bladder
Caput XL.	 Chapter Forty
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	 When weakness and softening of the bladder occur due to cold and moisture, to the point where the patient cannot retain urine, then cauterize it at the lower part of the abdomen above the bladder, where the pubic hair begins, and cauterize with one cautery from the right side of the abdomen and another from the left. The length of this cautery should be according to the size of the thumbnail. Cauterize it also with a lower back cautery, or two if you need it, and it should be as previously mentioned, a hot cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	 On the Method of Cauterizing the Uterus
Caput XLI.	 Chapter Forty-One
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	 When cold and moisture occur in the uterus, preventing impregnation, causing its menses to be corrupt, delaying their onset, and pain occurring at their time of arrival, then it is necessary to cauterize it with three cauteries around the navel, as we have said in the cautery of the bladder, and also with a lower back cautery or two: and let the cautery be hot.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	 On the Method of Cauterizing the Shoulder for Dislocation
Caput XLII.	 Chapter Forty-Two ›
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	 When mucous humors are discharged to the shoulder joint, causing it to leave its place, and a sign of this is that one leg appears longer than the other when compared, and the location of the dislocation is found empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	 Therefore, the patient should be cauterized on that very joint with a similar circular cautery after marking it with caustic around the joint as it turns, so that the joint falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	 And let there be a cautery of the form that preceded in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	 If this cautery is not present, then cauterize it with three cauteries, using a large olive-oil cautery; and let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the entire skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	 Concerning the manner of cauterizing for sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	 Chapter 43.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	 When pain occurs in the sciatic nerve and its cause is coldness and moisture, and the patient is treated with what was said about division (of humors), but it does not help, then you must free the patient from thick humors with stinking pills or artificial pills and similar ones.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	 Then cauterize him/her.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	 And the manner of cauterizing is according to two methods: either a cautery with drying medicines or a cautery with fire. ︎
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	 A cautery with fire is according to many methods.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	 One of which is that you should cauterize above the sciatic nerve itself with three triangular cauteries, in this manner.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	 And make them with a good or bad depth.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	 And let the space between each cautery be as thick as a finger; and let the cautery be an olive-oil one.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	 Sometimes, however, the cautery is made in the middle above the head of the sciatic nerve itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	 Why are there four cauteries?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	 And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose form preceded in the cauterization for dislocation of the sciatic nerve, let there be one, so that the circle contains the entire sciatic nerve. ︎ ︎
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	 And burn through the thickness of the entire skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	 This is the manner of cauterizing for sciatica when the pain is attached to the sciatic nerve itself and does not extend as far as the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	 If, however, it extends to the hip and leg, then cauterize it with two cauteries on the hip, over the place where the sick person indicates there is pain, and with your cautery four fingers above the pubic bone briefly; let the cautery be knife-like.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	 And let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	 But if the sick person indicates that the pain extends to near the toes, then cauterize him there where he indicates with a needle-pointed cautery, three or four times, or more, as needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	 And if he indicates that the pain is under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize him there with one knife-like cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	 And beware in all your cauterizations that you do not end with the cautery to the point where you burn a nerve or a large artery and thus bring about a harmful evil or contraction upon the sick person.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	 And I myself have seen one and another of those who cauterized above the pubic bone and ended in cauterizing to the point where the leg swelled until a tumor reached the foot, and the whole foot was pierced and completely corrupted; then an abdominal rupture occurred, and death followed.  />
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	 If the pain is in two places at once, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	 And some wise men have said regarding the cauterization of the ankle, whose cautery is this manner.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	 Make a similar needle from iron, whose diameter is half the palm's width; and let its tip be according to the thickness of an almond, or a little less; and inside that needle let there be another smaller needle.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	 And let the space that is between every needle be according to the size of the thumb's knuckle; and let the needles be open from both sides; and let their height be like a knuckle, or two knuckles; and make for them a handle from iron fittingly attached to the needles.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	 Then it should be heated over fire until it glows and emits sparks; then place it on a box of sea urchins in the patient's sickbed, on the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	 Cauterize him with three round cauteries at once.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then leave him for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	 Afterward, apply plasters with butter, and let the wound remain open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with ointment until he is cured.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	 Al-Zahrawi said: We have used this type of cautery, O my son, only rarely because of the terrifying appearance of it, and we find few who would wait upon him.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	 Yet it is one of the good cauteries for those who can endure it, and whoever finds its place will find benefit from it.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	 The cautery is made with adhering medicines, as you make two boxes with perforated hinges into which descends the bolt of its door made of iron or steel, the length of the wall, and at their height are two knobs or something similar.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	 And let the space between them be as thick as a finger, and let them be open at both ends, and let them contain each other according to this shape.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	 Then place it on the box of sea urchins, with the patient lying on his healthy side.  />
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	 And press your hand firmly upon the box of sea urchins.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	 Then pour between the two circles hot water that has been heated briefly by fire, and let it be held for an hour of time; and the patient must endure its biting and burning, because he will find its bite like fire until the biting ceases.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 Then lift your hand with the instrument and wipe away all the hot water from the sea urchins with fresh water; then leave it for three days.  />  />
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	 And put butter on it, until the blackness of the burn is removed; and leave it for some days, and pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	 For it is the last help.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	 But if the pain extends to the hip or thigh, make for it a plaster containing water, as you have made for the ankle evenly.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	 And this is the way of hot water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the correction of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	 Take alkali and non-extinguished lime, one part of each; grind both together, and put them into a new pot whose bottom is perforated with one small hole, according to the quantity that admits the very radius itself; and place under the pot another glass pot, and pour over the alkali and lime sweet water that submerges both by one finger width. After which you press it well with your hand: and leave the pot until the sharp water descends into the lower part of the glass pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	 Then collect all that water and pour it over another lime; and distill until it clarifies.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	 For then it will be very strong acidity, which is used in many medical procedures and in the cauterization of other members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	 Because it performs the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	 And among the medicines with which the ankle is also cauterized are casia and honey of the almond tree, and lime with soap, so that both are mixed.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	 And Galen indeed reported the cure of some ancient man, by which he was cured of pain in the ankle and sciatic vein; and he greatly praised its effectiveness. 》
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	 And he said that he did not need any other cure, and that he was cured in one application, until he reported that perhaps he entered the bath carried by men, and came out of it already healthy.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	 And it is thus: take from the green seitarag; and if the green one is not found, take the fresh dry one; grind very finely with some fat, and place on the wound where there is pain, whether on the leg or in the hip; bind it and leave for three hours, or as long as the patient feels a lessening of the burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	 Then put him in a bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	 When his body becomes wet, place him on the stool.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	 For the pain goes away and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	 And know that no one should use cautery with these medicines except after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	 And Dioscorides said that goat dung, when used to cauterize the sciatic vein, benefits it; and the cautery is made in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	 Take wool and soak it in old oil, and place it on the deep spot which is between the thumb of the foot and the heel, and it is closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	 Then take dry goat dung and burn it in the fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	 Then place it on the wool and leave it until it goes out.
Deinde itera illud.	 Then repeat that process.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	 Do not stop doing this until the sensation reaches the middle of the wound and the pain ceases.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	 And this type of cautery is called a cow's cautery.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	 ¶ On the Cautery for Back Pain
Caput XLIIII.	 Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	 Sometimes pain occurs in the back due to various causes such as a fall, a blow, or excessive evacuation, and similar things, from an influx of cold and moist matter; and indeed cautery is not indicated except for this type alone, which comes from an influx of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	 It is necessary therefore after the evacuation of the patient with foul pills and similar ones, that they be made on the back where there is pain, three lines according to the width of the almeida itself, after you mark with encaustic in each line five or more cauteries, as many as the patient's tolerance allows by its virtue; and let the cauterization be done with a cautery needle.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	 And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries using a median nail-shaped cautery in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	 About the method of cauterizing in a small hump.
Caput XLV.	 Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	 This disease often happens to very young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	 And the sign of its beginning in children is that a stricture occurs during breathing while raising and moving, and it is found in the last vertebrae of the back and their joints, which has already begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	 When you see this and wish to treat it, then cauterize with a cautery that is round in shape like this. ︎
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	 And let the cautery cover all parts of the vertebrae equally. If you wish, cauterize around the vertebra with a pointed cautery in two or three lines, and let the points be close together. ︎
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	 Then care for the place until it heals as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	 And beware of administering a cautery to a hump caused by a nerve spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	 About the method of cauterizing in gout and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	 Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	 When joint pains are caused by cold humors which are dispersed to any member of the body, then when they occur in the feet, according to the custom of physicians, it is called gout properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	 When, therefore, podagra of cold cause is being treated with methods of healing, and the pains are not removed, then cautery will remove them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	 And it should be cauterized after evacuation around the joint of the foot with many cauteries; and let the cautery be olive oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	 Whose form is this.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	 And if you need to prick on the sole of the foot, then do it with the cautery point.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	 If the pains ascend to the knees or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize it on every knee with three or four cauteries from all sides, with the same cautery Clavus.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	 If, however, you need more of this cautery, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	 And do not immerse your hand with the cautery; rather, let it be about as thick as the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	 But if the pains ascend to the knees and back, then administer what we said about the cautery in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	 If the pains are only in the hands, then prick around the joints, as if two lines were rolled up.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	 But if any pain remains in the fingers, then prick them, one prick on each joint and on the web of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	 If, however, after days the pains ascend to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both from all sides. xspace
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	 And do not weaken the patient by a good diet or reception of medicines. xspace ︎
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	 For if there is a good regimen and phlegm is evacuated, it will be healed with the help of God by this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	 ¶ On the manner of cauterizing in hernias.
Caput XLVII.	 Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	 When hernia occurs in the groin and the intestine or bladder descends to the testicle, and this is a recent occurrence; then you should advise the patient to stop eating on that day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	 And let him use purgatives so that his feces may pass from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	 Then have him sit between your hands on his back: and tell him to hold his breath until it comes out or the intestine appears.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	 Then bring him back with your fingers, and mark it with a cauterizing iron above the anus, with a mark whose end is like half of a circle towards the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	 Then heat the cauterizing iron, which has this shape, until it brings forth white matter and casts off tiny particles.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	 Then return the intestine or the hernia to its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	 Then let the assistant place his hand on the spot so that the intestine does not come out: and you have already opened between the patient's thighs and placed a cushion under him, and another servant is over his thighs, and another over his chest who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	 Then place the cauterizing iron on the very mark, with your hand holding the cauterizer straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	 And hold him until you reach his mouth with it: or do the same thing again if you did not reach his mouth the first time.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	 And be careful to watch the exit of the intestine during your cauterization, lest you burn it and cause death or great harm to the patient through it.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	 And know that when you do not reach the mouth with the cauterizer, your operation is of no use.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	 And it is necessary for the cauterizer for infants to be thin according to their size. }}{
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with other ointments until he is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	 And let the patient lie on his back for forty days, until the wound is closed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	 And it is necessary to place his food during the time of his treatment so that it may soften his belly, so that the intestine does not come out at the effort and expulsion. ]{}
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	 Then, when he wishes to rise after forty days, administer a well-made bandage and let him hold it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	 And let him be kept from work, and from filling himself with food and drink, and from loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	 For when he follows this regimen, he is healed completely.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	 And I will discuss the treatment of hernias with incision in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	 But when a hernia occurs in the rest of the belly and is recent, and you wish that it should not increase, then cauterize his hernia with a round cautery according to its size: and let what is burnt be a third of it from then on.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	 Then treat him as we have said, and it will not increase.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	 And now some of the ancients have said that a hernia should be cauterized with a triangular cautery in this manner.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	 After it is marked with the cautery and a line is placed which is equal to its width on the upper side of the hernia, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	 And place your hand in the middle with a claw-shaped cautery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	 But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	 ¶ On the manner of cauterizing for pains due to a fall or blow.
Caput XLVIII.	 Chapter 48
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	 When pain occurs in certain members from a fall or blow, and that pain persists for a long time, and medical treatment with drugs does not help it, then it is necessary to cauterize with a point cautery.  />
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	 And let the cautery be that of every member according to its size and weakness, and its debility, and its strength, and the place of the twist, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	 If he is then cured by the first cautery, that is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	 If not: then repeat over that cautery.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	 Because the habit of these pains is to pass from one member to another which is near it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Therefore, you must follow them with a cautery, until the sick person heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	 Concerning the method of cauterizing in leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	 Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	 Sometimes lepers are helped by a cautery to a great degree.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	 And especially the kind of leprosy which arises from the corruption of phlegm and black bile; when you want to cauterize it, consider its strength.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	 If therefore the leprosy is in its beginning stage and you have treated it with what was said in the division, and it neither descends nor stands still; and you fear that the corruption will spread to the whole complexion of the patient; then cauterize him five times on the head: one in the middle of the head, known as the navel; a second below this towards the forehead at the end of the hairline; two above each corner [of the forehead]; and one behind on the occipital bone. 》
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	 And the last time, place your hand with the cautery briefly on it until it leaves a small mark in the shape of an imprint, and let the scales be separated from it; so that the expiration of thick vapors may be relieved from it; and also cauterize the spleen with a cautery, as was said before.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	 But if the leprosy is already spread over the patient and clearly visible; then you should cauterize with these cauteries which we mentioned on the head, and one cautery on the tip of the nose, and two cauteries on each cheek, and two cauteries on each shoulder, and six on the shoulders of the back, and a large one on the thighs near the buttocks, and one on the anus itself; and two on the flanks; that is, one on each whole flank, and two on each knee, one on each whole knee, and two on each shoulder, and two on each elbow, and two on each nipple of his chest; and cauterize him over every joint from the joints of his fingers and toes, and cauterize over each heel of his feet, and the palms of his hands. 》
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	 And beware of the nerves that are above the last part of the heel, lest you burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	 And sometimes it is cauterized with a cautery on the tip of the pubis, and another on the tip of the stomach, and another on the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	 And know that the more you apply the cautery, it is a greater benefit and more effective.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	 And know that the sick person does not find pain in the cautery as the healthy person does; for this reason, because his body is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	 And the cauteries should be according to size and smallness of the limbs and joints; as it was explained earlier in the types of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then care for the cauteries with flour of barley mixed with honey, and continue the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing in a coma.
Caput L.	 Chapter L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	 When a limb is in a coma and is treated with medicines, oils, and plasters, but does not heal, then cauterize the comatose limb with cauteries, according to the size or smallness of the limb.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	 And let your cautery penetrate a little into the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	 And sometimes it is cauterized for a certain coma that happens to the hand and foot, at the spinal column of the back near the exit of the nerves that move that limb; and the coma will be removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	 Indeed, no one should attempt this unless he is knowledgeable in the anatomy of the limbs and the exit of the nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for paralysis.
Caput LI.	 Chapter LII.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	 When ancient paralysis occurs and nothing helps from the practices of medicine; then cauterize it a little with a deep cautery according to the thickness of the skin, until the whiteness is removed and its color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with herb flour, and lentils with rose oil, and hart's-tongue fern leaves, and the blood of a dove, and the blood of a swallow: from each let there be one part. All these are to be mixed together and smeared on cloth, and they should adhere to the place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	 On the method of cauterizing for cancer.
Caput LII.	 Chapter 52.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	 When the cancer is beginning and you wish to stop it, then cauterize it with a round cautery around its edge, as if rolling it along.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	 However, the wise have said that it should be cauterized with the last point in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	 But this does not seem right to me, because I fear that it might ulcerate; and indeed I have seen this happen several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	 And it is better to cauterize around its edge with a circle, as we said; or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	 On the method of cauterizing for abscesses.
Caput LIII.	 Chapter 53.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	 When someone has an abscess and it is delayed in ripening either because of an excess causing it or because the patient is weak and of little blood, or because of the time and you wish to hasten the ripening of the abscess, then cauterize around its edge with many small points.  ¶ De modo cauterizandi in Carbonculo.
Deinde dimitte eam.	 Then leave it alone.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	 For it will hasten on its own with the ripening.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	 But if you wish to perforate it with a cautery, then heat the cautery whose form is this.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	 And place it in the middle of the abscess, until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery be from that which follows the patient, so that the course of the pus may be relieved.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	 Then care for him until he is healed.  ¶ De modo cauterizandi in Unguis cariosis.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	 "On the method of cauterizing for a malignant ulcer.
Caput LIIII.	 Chapter 42
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	 "A malignant ulcer is nothing but corruption walking within a member, and it eats away at the very same member: just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	 "If you see a malignant ulcer in a place that can withstand cautery and fire, then use much burning with both small and large red-hot irons, according to what is suitable for that place where the ulcer is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	 "Then cauterize it from all sides until you have completely rooted out all the corruption, so that nothing of it remains whatsoever.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	 "Then leave it for three days and place powdered sulfur mixed with oil on the cauterized spots, until all the scabs and any corruption are completely removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	 "Then treat it with ointments that promote flesh growth.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	 "If, after three days, you see that healthy flesh has grown where there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	 "And if not, then repeat the cautery on the remaining parts of the corrupted areas.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	 "And let the malignant ulcer be treated sometimes with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	 "For it arises in the place of the cautery." xspace
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	 "However, cautery with fire is a faster remedy: and I have already said that its cauterization with sharp medicine was divided; receive it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	 "On the method of cauterizing fingernails and warts.
Caput LV.	 Chapter 55
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	 "Frequently this ailment occurs in the lower parts of the feet; it is a thick, dense thing that hurts the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	 "And there are two methods of cautery for them: cautery with fire and cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	 "When using fire, make the cautery a concave, hollow one like the feather of a vulture, made from iron, according to the size that contains the entire nail on all sides; and let it have thin edges.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	 Then place the cauterizing iron on the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	 Then turn the hand with the cautery around the nail until the iron reaches the depth of the nail, and leave it alone for three days until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	 Then apply a poultice of crushed wild mallows mixed with salt upon it, and leave the poultice on overnight.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	 For it will be eradicated from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat the place with a flesh-generating ointment until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	 But if they do not convert and often occur on the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet, then administer cautery with hot water to them. And it is as follows: take a pipe made of bronze, iron or the quill of a vulture; and place it on the nail or wart.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	 Then pour a little hot water into the pipe; hold your hand and turn it with some pressure for a short time, so that the edge of the pipe is imprinted on the root of the nail, and the hot water finds its way to the depth, to the root of the nail; and let the patient wait over the burning sensation of the hot water for about an hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	 Then leave it alone, for the nail will be eradicated with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	 Do this one by one with each of them, until you have treated all those that are on the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	 Then treat them after they have been eradicated with that which generates flesh from ointments.  />
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for tremors.
Caput LVI.	 Chapter LVI.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	 When trembling occurs to someone from cold in the nerve, or from quartan fever, or something else, then you should cauterize them with four or five cauteries on each vertebra of the back, and between every vertebra a cautery, and one cautery on the chest, and one on the stomach.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	 The tremor calms with olive oil cautery, and the health of the cold sickness speeds up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	 About the way to cauterize Albathir.
Caput LVII.	 Chapter 57
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	 Sometimes foul Albathir are expelled from the body, that is, pustules which come from coarse corrupted matters.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	 Therefore, when they first appear, they should be cauterized over every head of the pustule with a subtle cautery and with myrtle wood, whose end has been set on fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	 Or with the root of long aristrolochia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	 Or with a lenticular cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	 And sometimes they are cauterized at the beginning of their expulsion in this manner: and they do not increase; and the excess causing them is broken up, and healed from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	 However, it should be done after evacuation with bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	 About the way to cauterize in the flow of blood from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	 Chapter 58
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	 It often happens that there is a flow of blood from an artery cut in a wound, which occurs externally, or at the incision of an aposteme, or a limb cautery and similar things; and it is difficult to stop it.  />
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	 Therefore, when this happens to someone, quickly bring your hand to the opening of the artery and place your index finger on it; and press hard until the blood is blocked under your finger and nothing comes out from there.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then place a small olive oil cautery in the fire and many more, and blow on them until they become very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then take one [of the hot cauteries], whether small or large, according to the wound and the place where the artery is broken, and place the cautery on that vein after you quickly remove your finger; and hold the cautery until the blood is stopped.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	 If it is expelled with the elevation of the finger from the orifice of the artery and you extinguish the cautery, then quickly take another cautery from those prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Therefore do not stop doing it with one after the other until the blood is cut off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	 And be careful not to burn the nerve that is there, lest some other harm come upon the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	 And know that when blood flows from the artery, then it is not possible to cut it off: especially when the artery is large, except with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	 Or with a cautery, as we have said.
