Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	 Or by extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For when it is extracted, its ends are drawn together and the blood is cut off.  \\( \text { } \) Aut cum ligatura, quando non est ligata.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	 Or by tying with a strong thread for ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	 Or let there be applied to it medicines of astringent nature, which have the property of cutting off blood, and let them be tied with a decent constriction using a bandage.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	 But he who administers its cutting off with a ligature and constriction with a bandage or the application of burning substances and similar things does not benefit him at all, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	 But if this happens to someone and there is no doctor present, nor any medicine: then let him begin by pressing with the index finger on the orifice of that vein, as we have said, and constraining it very strongly until the blood is obstructed from the upper part of the wound and over the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	 And let the finger not be removed, and always pour over it very cold water until the blood freezes, thickens, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	 And meanwhile, he should consider whether anything is needed from a cautery or from medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	 End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	 Liber Chirurgiae Albucasis Secunda Pars
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	 § De incisione, perforatione, et phlebotomia in vulnereis, et similibus.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	 Nunc dabimus capitulum de incisione uulneris in quo conueniens est ut incidatur, et ubi non convenit ut incidatur, et de perforatione uulneris, et de phlebotomia, et ubi et quando conueniet illa.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	 Et in fine dixi quod omnis ars habet quaedam generalia, et aliquid speciale. ¶ Hoc est primum capitulum liber secundus de arte medica.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	 Primum quod necesse est cognoscere est locus et natura vulneris, et sic scies ad quid est conueniens. Vulnus enim in loco est loci naturae et potestas. ¶ Est et aliud genus uulnerum quod non est secundum naturam, sed extra naturam.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	 Et cum haec cognoscere potueritis, scietis ubi est necesse incidere et ubi non est opus.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	 Et ideo est necesse ut sciatur ubi incideretur et ubi non oportet incidere, et sciatis qualiter incidendum sit, et quod non est incisio sine periculo, nec est perforatio sine metu. ¶ Est igitur incisio, et cura uulneris, et incisio super apostema, et apertio exiturae, et extractionem sagittae, et incisio super lapidem.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	 Necesse est igitur ut omnis medicus sit prudens et habeat intelligentiam, et possit discernere inter ea quae conueniant et illa quae non conueniant, nec incidat in loco qui non debet incidi.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	 Et ideo necesse est ut scias loca periculosa, et incisio quae est extra periculum, et curatio quae conuenit uulnerei, et ubi non conuenit.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	 And with sickness from fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	 And among them is one who gives his flute to you and enriches you with it, hoping for health, but his sickness is deadly.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	 Therefore, it is not right that you agree with the one who comes to you from among them whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	 And let your caution be stronger than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	 And do not presume anything from it until after certain knowledge verifies the praiseworthy outcome that reaches you. 》
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	 And use for the care of all your sick patients the prognosis and indication of that which is suitable for their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	 For in this lies your aid for the acquisition of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	 May God inspire you, O sons, with his understanding, and may he not take away your guidance and inspiration from you; for that is in his hand. 》 》
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	 And I myself have arranged this chapter by chapters according to what preceded in the cautery chapter from the neck down to the feet, so that your search for what you want from it and need is made easier.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	 ¶ On treating water that collects on the heads of boys.
Caput I.	 Chapter I
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	 Know that this illness often happens to children at birth, or when the midwife presses the child's head without gentleness. 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	 And sometimes it happens also for an unknown cause that is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	 And I myself have not seen this sickness in anyone other than boys, and every one whom I saw from them hastened to death; therefore it seemed good to me to describe the treatment for it. 》 》 》 》 》 》 》
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	 And I myself saw a boy from them whose head was filled with water, and his head swelled daily until he could not sit up because of the size of his own head; and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	 And this moisture either gathers between the skin and bone, or it gathers beneath the bone on the surface of the spongy tissue.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	 And the operation on it, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the abscess is small, then you should make a single incision in the middle of the head, its width being one finger's breadth: and let the length of the incision be as two fingers, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	 And this is the form of the trepan.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	 Therefore, if the moisture has increased more and the abscess is larger, then place those two incisions according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	 And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and its sign is that you see the sutures of the skull open on all sides; and when you press with your hand towards the inside, water is depressed, and it is not hidden from you: then you should make three incisions in the middle of the head in this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	 And after making the incision, extract all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	 Then bind the incisions with cloths and poultices.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	 Then dress it on top with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	 Then loosen the bandage, and care for the wound with compresses and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	 And do not stop binding the head equally.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	 And feed the patient with dry food of little moisture until the part is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	 And another method of incising is that you should look where the swelling of the abscess and collection of water appears.  />
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	 Because sometimes it is more on the back of the head, or the forehead, or on the right side, or on the left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	 Therefore, proceed with the incision where you see the abscess and filling of water: and divide it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	 And be careful not to cut an artery and cause a bleeding, and the patient dies from that bleeding along with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	 On the incision of arteries that are behind the ears.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	 When someone has a catarrh of the eyes or chest, and it persists and medical treatment is not helpful, then the final treatment for that person is the incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	 Therefore, when you want to incise them, the patient should shave his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	 Then rub the area with a rough cloth so that the arteries become apparent. 》
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	 Then let the patient tie his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	 Then observe where the vein pulsates.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 And the locations of both are the areas behind the ears that are depressed: and rarely are they hidden, except in certain people. 》 》
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	 Then mark both with cautery: and cut each with a spatula that is sharp on both sides, the cut reaching to the mouth: and let this be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	 And if you wish, insert the spatula under the artery, and cut it from above with the same cut.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	 And let the length of the cut be as two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	 For when the vein is cut, blood comes out with a pulsating flow, which jumps towards the inside with frequent leaps. 》 》 》
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	 But if the artery is not apparent to touch, then measure from the ear the length of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	 Then mark with cautery, and continue until you reach the mouth.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	 And what should be released from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you will release more or less than that.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	 The whole amount according to what appears to you from the strength of the patient and the fullness of his artery. 》 》 》 》 》 》
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	 Then observe at the wound. 》 》 》 》 》 》 》
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	 Then if there is anything remaining at the mouth from the cloth, cut it off so that a hot abscess does not form. Then bind the wound with linen cloths.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with ointment until he is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	 On the removal of arteries which are in the temples.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	 When someone suffers from an old headache or severe migraine due to sharp humors and heat in the temples, or an old harsh cold, or similar conditions, and is treated with appropriate medical methods but does not improve, we have found in these illnesses that removing the arteries from the temples, or cauterizing them, as we have described, is beneficial.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	 And the method of operating for their removal is that the patient should shave off the hairs on the temples and direct [his gaze] toward the visible artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	 For it shows itself to you by its own pulse and is rarely hidden except in a few people or due to extreme cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	 If it is hidden from you, then let the patient bind his head with any cloth of his; afterwards, rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	 Or apply steam to the place with hot water until it appears clearly to you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	 Then take the small scalpel that I have described before.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	 Then use it to cut away the skin easily until you reach the artery. ↑
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	 Then insert a hook into it and draw it upward until you pull it out of the skin, allowing it to emerge from all the layers beneath it.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	 But if the artery is thin, then wrap it around the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Then cut off a piece of it according to the length by which its ends are extended and contracted, so that there is no flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	 For if it is not cut or severed, the blood does not rise completely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	 Then drain off six ounces of blood until three [ounces] remain. ↑ ︎ ︎
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 If the artery is large, then you must tie it in two places with a double, strong thread of silk or gut, so that putrefaction does not occur before the wound heals and blood loss does not happen.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	 Then cut away the excess between the two ties.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	 Do this in that hour or another hour later.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	 And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery iron until the ends are cut off and it stands in place.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	 And this is better work unless the patient has a fever or is of hot constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	 Because cautery is one of those things which help to dry up moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	 Therefore it is a better remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	 And after the removal of the artery, the place should be filled with old cooked linseed and neatly made bandages placed over it. 》 》
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	 And after the dissolution, let it be scraped with dry medications that promote the growth of flesh and with ointments until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 But if, during the operation, there is bleeding from the artery, then hasten to cut it off with a cautery or to fill the place with wax, and keep your hand steady until the blood is stopped.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	 But if you have none of these at hand, then place your finger on the spot until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	 And sprinkle the spot with very cold water until it calms down and is tied off as needed.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	 And because the removal of a vein is easier and simpler than that of an artery, it should be cauterized with this two-bladed cautery; let the sharpness of the two blades be like that of a needle.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	 Nevertheless, they are much less sharp than two knives. 》 》 》
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	 Since they are sharp, like two knives, it hastens cold for both; and they do not cut the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	 Therefore, if there is some thickness to them, they retain the heat of fire and cut through the flesh quickly; for this reason, this operation is better than any other, easier, and more convenient.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	 Let the space between the two knives be equal to the thickness of a finger. After marking two places with caustic, place both very hot irons there until they reach the surface and cut the vein in two places so that what is between its ends may be extended.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	 For this caustic does not heal thoroughly.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	 And this is the form of the caustic.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	 ¶ On the treatment of persistent, sharp watering of the eyes.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	 When tears are persistent and their flow comes from the veins outside on top of the head, and no medicinal treatment with medicines helps, and you see the patient's face is already red, and they feel a sensation on their forehead like that of ants walking, and their eyes are weak, wet to the point that the hair around them is eroded away, and their eyelids are heated from the sharpness of the tears, then the ancients needed this operation for their treatment and called it "with the Sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	 And it is as if you command the patient to shave off the hair on their forehead.  />
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	 Then make three incisions in the forehead, equally spaced along its length; and let the length of each incision be about two fingers wide. Let one incision be at the midpoint of the forehead, another slightly above the hairline on either side, and the third at the far edge. Be careful not to cut the arteries that are on both sides. Keep your hand away from the extension of the jawbones, and let the total length of all the incisions be about three finger widths. And have a piece of sponge ready, or many dry cloths with which you can soak up the blood.  />
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	 Then insert a narrow spoon with two sharp tips, whose following is the shape.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	 From the incision that is on the side of the temple, to the second incision: and scrape off all the skin that is between the two incisions with a scalpel, which is above the mouth.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	 Then do the same from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	 Then remove that narrow spoon and insert another instrument into the first incision, which is called a sharp blade, gently from one side and not sharply from the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	 And place its sharp edge towards the flesh attached to the skin, and its gentle edge towards the mouth; and push it until it reaches the middle fissure; and cut with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except for what continues in the incision until it appears on the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	 Then do the same in the middle fissure up to the other fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	 And after an equal amount of blood has been allowed to run out, squeeze out the places from the clots of congealed blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	 Then place a bandage made from old linen cloth on every fissure, and put on them small woolen pads soaked in wine or oil, or vinegar.  />
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 And be sure that no hot abscess forms.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	 And on the third day, loosen the bandage and administer a large amount of decoction with warm water.  />
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with balm ointment and other remedies for wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	 ¶ On the treatment of sharp tears and colds to the eyes from inside the head.
Caput V.	 Chapter 5
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	 When someone has sharp, acrid, persistent colds; and you see their eyes are wasted, small, and the look in them is already weakened; and their eyelids have ulcers, and hairs fall from them, and there is a sharp, painful pain at the back of the head, followed by sneezing: then take from these events that those humors and colds do not come except from many veins.  />
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	 And a better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	 It is as though you were to instruct the patient to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	 Then make an incision in the middle of the forehead or slightly to one side across its width, and begin with the incision from the left temple towards the right: and let the incision go as far as the mouth: and keep your hand away from the temples which move during chewing; until the mouth is revealed: and dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	 Then separate the two lips of the incision with an old rag or with linens from flax.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then bind it on top with bandages; and moisten the bandages with wine and oil, so that no hot abscess may form.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	 And when you remove it, and see that the hot abscess is already diminishing; then it is necessary for you to scrape the mouth until new flesh begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	 Then care for him with the drying regimen that makes flesh grow, as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony, and prepare a plaster from them, and apply it to the newly growing flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	 ¶ On caring for what falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	 Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something like a stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a liquid, such as water and vinegar and things similar to them; or some sort of animal.  /> 12/5
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	 Therefore, when a stone or something like a stone that does not grow or increase falls into the ear, expose the ear to sunlight; and if you see the stone, then drip some of the oil of violets or sesame oil into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	 Then administer the extraction and make him sneeze with snuff, and plug the nostrils at the onset of sneezing, after you have placed shreds from cloth or wool around the ear, and stretch the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	 For often it escapes with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	 If it does not escape, then administer the extraction with gentle purgatives, that is, with subtle suppositories, whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	 Therefore if it escapes with the suppository, that is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	 And if not, then administer the extraction with a subtle blind hook of few folds.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	 Therefore if it does not escape through that [method], then make a tube from copper and insert the end of the tube into the ear hole very deeply; and plug what is around the tube with softened wax mixed with oil, so that there is no path for air except through the tube: then extract with your strong attraction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	 For often it escapes with what we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	 If it does not escape this way, then take from henbane or from glue, that is, prepared birdlime, a small amount; and place it on the end of a rod after you have wrapped around it a clean cloth neatly arranged: then insert it into the ear hole with ease, after you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	 Therefore if it does not escape with all that we have described, then hasten to cut [it], before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	 And the manner of the incision is, as for a bloodletting, first make an incision on the temporal artery; and draw out blood from him according to his strength.  />
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	 Then make the sick person sit between your hands, and turn his ear upwards, and find a small incision at the root of the ear in its fatty part in a depressed place itself; and let the incision be lunar-shaped until you reach the stone; then remove it with what is possible for you from instruments.  />  />
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then attend to the split from your time with speed, and care for it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	 But if the falling object is one of those seeds which grow and swell, then extract it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	 However, if it does not obey you to come out, then take a thin, subtle probe according to this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	 And perform with it the cutting of that type of seed which falls into the ear and does not do this when you think that the seed is already moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you divide it into many pieces; then remove them with tweezers or with a fine hook or with suction, as we have said, for its removal is made easier. 》
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	 In the case of water which enters the ear, the sick person should use sneezing first of all; and now he has filled his ear with some old cooked grain: and it is lying on that ear which contains the water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	 Therefore if it comes out through it, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	 And if it does not come out, then take many small stones according to the length of the finger, thin and soft, and heat them slightly with fire, and let the sick person put one into his ear canal; and let him stand on one foot from that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone which is in the ear. 》 》 》
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	 Therefore he should not cease doing this with stone after stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	 And now the water comes out so that you take one reed or rush and put one end into the ear; and light the other end with fire until most of it is burned up.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	 Then repeat this with another reed, and do this many times until all the water comes out; and remove it with a tube as we have said above regarding the stone. 》 》 》 》 》 》
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	 In the extraction of an animal entering it, if it is a small body, like a flea and similar to it, care for it as I said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	 But if it is of a large body, which can be perceived by the senses: then administer its extraction with tweezers and hooks, and its process is easier than all that are held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	 But in the extraction of a worm born in the ear, when you care for it with what we said in division and in the discussion on drops, your treatment is not beneficial; then you must examine the ear in sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	 Therefore, if something appears there from the worms, then extract it with tweezers or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	 But if nothing appears there, then take a tube whose form is this: narrow at the bottom, wide at the top; and insert its fine tip into the ear according to the amount that the patient can tolerate; then suck with strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	 Do this many times, until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	 But if they do not obey you to come out, then fill around the tube with wax, as I said about the pebble.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	 But if they do not come out with that which we said, then administer the drops that have been found effective by the ancients for the destruction of worms; and you will find this in the discussion on drops.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	 And let your pouring be such that you pour oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	 As you see, make it of silver or brass, narrow at the bottom, in which there should be a small hole, wide at the top.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	 Therefore, let what is in the cavity of the tube be made neatly from brass.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	 And if you wish, take a stick, and wrap a fine thread around its tip with decent wrapping; then pour oil or juice, or whatever you want from these medicines into the tube; and let the tube be in the ear; then insert the stick with the thread on top, and press it with your hand with moderate pressure until the oil is pushed into the cavity of the ear, and the patient feels it inside; and what is poured into the ear should already be warmed a little with fire; and beware that what is distilled into it is not very cold; for medicines do not tolerate this.  />
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	 "On the Care for an Ear Injury
Caput VII.	 Chapter Seven
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	 Sometimes infants come out of their mothers' wombs unruptured.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	 And it has also happened to some people that an ear injury occurs in the inner part of the ear due to a wound or fleshy growth there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	 And this injury sometimes occurs deep within the ear canal, which does not affect vision; and sometimes it happens near the outer part of the ear canal, and then it affects vision.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	 Therefore, that which occurs deep within the ear and which sight does not perceive is difficult to heal in most situations.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	 And in the case where vision is affected, it is necessary to place the ear of the patient in the sunlight and look into it; then if you see an apparent injury, open it with a fine probe whose shape follows this one [drawing], its tip should have a small flat area at the end, part of which should be sharp: and the rest of the probe should be smooth on both sides so that it does not harm the ear. 》
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	 Therefore, if the injury is due to flesh growing in the inner part of the ear, then hold it with a fine hook and cut it away with great ease until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	 If the injury is deep within the ear, then take a thin, smooth wire and heat it briefly with fire; then insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	 If you feel the injury with it, which the patient perceives with difficulty in hearing, try to open it gently: and be careful not to wound the nerves of the ear. 》
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	 Then place in the ear a piece of cloth according to the width of the ear canal, which you have rolled in Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are sure about the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	 Or take a piece of cloth and dip it in rose water, and sprinkle ground cinnamon on it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	 If you see the ear already infected with pus, then you must extract the hair, and place it together with another hair that you will wrap in a rag made with rose oil, until the hot infection subsides; then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	 But if there is a flow of blood, then submerge a sponge or cloth in cold water and place the ear upon it; and use the remaining treatment that cuts off the flow of blood as described in the treatise on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	 On the care for sty in the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter 8
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	 These styles that occur in the eyelids of the eye are sometimes wet and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	 Therefore it is necessary to hold them with tweezers or with a hook, and cut them off from their roots with a knife.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	 Then place powdered alum on the places.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	 But if there is a flow of blood from them, then cauterize them with a fine lens-shaped cautery. ●
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	 And it is better to cauterize them after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	 For often they return when something remains from their roots. ● ●
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	 And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned up and do not return. ● ●
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	 ¶ On the care for chalazions in the eyelids of the eye. ● ● ●
Caput IX.	 Chapter 9 ● ● ●
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	 It often happens in the eyelids that something similar to a chalazion appears in its strength and hardness, and on account of this it is called a hailstone; and it is an accumulation of thick humidity in the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	 The operation on them is that you should then see if it is a hailstone extending from the eyelid, which moves in every direction and its substance is soft. ● ● ● ●
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	 "Therefore, find over it a crack of equal width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	 "Then excoriate it from all sides with ease until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	 "Then suspend it with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	 "However, if you cannot cut it off unless after you penetrate the eyelid with a slight incision, then that could harm the patient in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 "But if the crack is large: then stitch it up and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	 "And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	 "For an ointment restores and heals it.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	 "And if the gravel is sloping toward the inner surface of the ear, then turn back the eyelid and suspend the gravel with a hook; besides needing an incision, press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	 "If the eyelid is stretched by the incision, that will not harm in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	 "Then wash the eye with salt water after removing the gravel, and care for the area with what heals until the patient is well.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	 "§ On the treatment of trachoma of the eyelids.
Caput X.	 Chapter 10
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	 "Trachoma is the grease that forms in the membranes of the upper eyelid, and it most often occurs in children. It weighs down their eyes, and they frequently have morning colds, unable to look at the sun because tears rush to them, which is why you see them always lying on their faces and sleeping on them, and their eyelids under the eyebrows are wet from inflammation. The protruding Axirnath is visible in the eye, and when you press the area with your fingers, you feel the Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the way of performing it is that the patient places their head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	 Then take a linen cloth and prepare in it a bandage, and make from that bandage a circle according to the size that contains Axirnath from every side.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	 Then place it over [the wound], and press it with your fingers from all sides, so that Axirnath collects in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	 Then find in the middle of that moisture with a thin blade making incisions across [the circle], and let the incision not be deeper than that which is made in venesection.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	 Or you should find the entire skin, until you reach Axirnath, for in many arrangements proceeds Axirnath from the incision according to the shape of a white fatty piece.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	 Therefore, take it out with the cloth that you have placed between your fingers on the outside; and you turn your hand to the right and to the left, until it is dispersed; and beware not to add [anything] in the incision, so that you do not reach with the blade to the eye and injure it. ➤
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	 However, if Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the incision, then add a little [more] easily into the incision until Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	 Then take it out as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	 Then soak the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on [the wound], and bind it with bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	 And there are people who grind salt and place it in the depth of the incision, so that it may liquefy what remains from that moisture.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then care for [the wound], until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	 However, if a hot abscess occurs there, then care for it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	 ¶ On the types of ataxia of the eye, that is, when the eyelid of the eye is softened, whereby it causes a disturbance as if it should not.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	 When hairs grow in the eyelids besides their natural course and become long, they harm the eye and cause various diseases, such as constant tearing, swelling of the eyelids, and opacities, until it leads to the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	 And ataxia of the eye is treated in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	 Either by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	 Or with a caustic medicine, as previously stated in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	 Or ataxia is treated by incision and suture.  />Aut per punctum.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	 Or with cannulas, as I will describe.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 You should place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	 Then, turn back the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	 If it turns back, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	 And if it does not: insert a needle with thread into the lower part of the eyelid and pass the needle with the thread through the upper part, placing it near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hairs grow. Pull the thread to the top along with the eyelid and turn it back with a rod.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	 Then, find the space inside the eyelid beneath the added hairs using a blunt instrument from the greater lacrimal gland to the lesser one.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	 Then, pull out the thread and place a small piece of cotton or cloth under the eyelid; then mark on the eyelid with an enkauster in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	 However, the figure should be made according to the size and thickness of the eyelid, as it varies among individuals.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	 For there are those who need to have cut from the eyelid a large quantity, according to the amount that swells up in the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	 Then when you find the space between the two lines that you marked, begin from the larger tear duct to the smaller one, and let there be a single slit near the natural hairs, like the thickness of a hair.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	 Then introduce a hook into one of the two corners of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	 Then scrape it off entirely.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	 Then join the two lips with a stitch using a fine woolen thread and needle; clean away the blood and let what remains of the threads adhere to the two eyebrows with some unguents, if you wish to do so; otherwise, it does not matter.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	 Then leave the stitch and threads for three or four days; after that, take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	 And if you wish, leave the wound without a stitch and care for it with something that dries and constricts it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	 For the eyelid is raised at the sealing of the wound and its joining; but it will be better in the future.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	 This method of treatment was taught by the ancients to Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	 However, there is concern for the patient with this method, and it is from good practice, and there is no fear about it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	 And there is another method in Ataxmir as well, and it is to mark on the eyelid a figure like that of a myrtle leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	 Then raise the eyelid with three separate or joined hooks according to this following figure; then cut away what is excessive with small scissors according to this figure, with an equal incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	 But if you cannot hold the hook and it is not equal, then take a needle with thread on it and insert it in the middle of the figure; and introduce another thread near the larger tear duct, and a second one near the smaller tear duct; and join the threads between your fingers with equality. 》
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	 Then raise your hand with an equal elevation: and raise the skin over which the scar is marked, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bring together the two lips of the wound with stitches: and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	 But if an abscess occurs at your incision or fracture: cauterize that abscess with a hot iron and similar things from the soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	 And sometimes it happens to the eyelid that its hairs turn inward.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	 Therefore, you should use what we said about the incision: but the stitching of both is more artistic.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	 § On treating Ataxia with Cannabis.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	 And it is as if you turn the eyelid and cut the crack that is inside, as I have said.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	 Then skillfully make two reeds or two thin pieces of wood whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and their width should be less than the width of the spatula; and you have already cut at the ends of both from both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	 Then bring both together with skill over that which protrudes from the eyelid of the eye, and tie the two reeds strongly on both sides, and leave it for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	 For the skin, having been tightly bound, will die, blacken, and rot until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	 If it is delayed, then cut it with scissors.  />
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	 When it has solidified, raise the eyelid; and the hairs will not irritate.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	 And this is the form of the two reeds which you make according to this figure and quantity in length and width.  />  />
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	 § On raising irritating hairs in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	 Chapter XII
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	 Operation in that is, that you should take a fine needle and introduce into it a fine thread of silk gently.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	 Then you will bind the ends together with two very fine knots; and let the length of the threads be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	 Then prepare another fine thread under it briefly, and if you wish, bind its ends together.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	 Then let the patient place his head on your lap, and let it be near the sun so that the operation can be seen; because this is a fine or minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	 Then introduce the needle with the thread into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate quickly into the eyelid until you pull it out above the natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	 Then draw up the hair over the thread; and insert that hair into the thread, if it is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	 Then draw your hand with it until the hair comes out with the thread from the eyelid together with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	 But if the thread is drawn and the hair does not come out with it, draw the thread downward with the other thread that you prepared in it until the thread comes out from the upper hole, and you see it with the eye; then draw the thread and the hair together, and pull both out, and close the eye; and leave it closed for two or three days, until the hair sticks to its place, and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	 But if the hair is short, then either join to it a long hair from the natural hairs and pull it up with it; or leave it until it lengthens after some time, and then pull it up yourself.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	 On the care of the entropion which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter XIII
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	 When this entropion occurs in the eye, it is called leporine.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 And this is either congenital or acquired.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	 Therefore, it occurs accidentally from the healing of a wound, or an incision, or cauterization, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	 And the method of operation is that you should locate that healing and separate its lips, and place between them a bandage of linen, and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	 And you should not use in its treatment things that dry and constrict, for if you do this, the condition returns worse than before. Rather, use in it things that soften, such as fenugreek; and an infusion of water in which mallow has been boiled, flax seed, and diacolon ointment mixed with some oil. And wrap a bandage with it, and treat it with this.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	 The treasure of your treatment is to strive by every means that it does not heal according to its first shape.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	 And this operation that we have mentioned is nothing other than a correction of the axlatrati, so that the shape of the place does not completely return.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	 ¶ Concerning the treatment of axlatrati that occurs in the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkle or contraction upward toward the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	 This axlatrati that occurs below is what is truly called axlatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	 And it is either congenital or acquired.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	 And the acquired type occurs from a wound, or a fissure, or cauterization, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	 And the method of operation is to take a needle with two threads attached, and dip it in ink, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal gland to the right lacrimal gland until the thread comes out at both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	 Then stretch the flesh upward with a needle, and cut it with a broad spatula.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	 If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it should be, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	 And if not, take a reed and place it in the slit, and turn the eyelid with it. And find two slits on the inner side of the eyelid, and let their ends be from the two angles of the incision, until they meet and form an angle; so that when they come together, it forms this shape, and it is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	 Then remove that flesh to the extent that its sharp lower edge reaches the part that follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	 Then join the separated parts; or sew it with a wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	 Then treat them with what we have said about softening medicines and ointments, until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	 And if entropion occurs from the slit, or sewing, or cautery, then you must make a flat incision under the eyelashes of the eyelid, even as it has been described before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	 Then separate between the two lips with ointment, as we have said.  />
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	 And the end of the discourse on the treatment of entropion, whether it is above or below, is that this operation be carried out according to the preparation of the form of entropion.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	 For indeed, it has many different forms; and the skillful practitioner prepares his ingenuity with whatever method is possible for him, so that he may bring back the shape to its natural form or very close to it, and even the patient himself, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in most dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	 ¶ On the adherence of the eyelid of the eye with the conjunctiva or cornea.  />
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	 Sometimes this consolidation happens to many people, so that the upper eyelid fuses with the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	 You should therefore insert the point of a needle under the eyelid and lift it up, or stretch it with a hook. Then cut the adhesion with a fine spatula, which should not be as sharp as the incising spatulas, but rather blunt for a short time, so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatula is removed without injuring the eye with its sharpness. And your incision should be as if you are scraping off that adhesion with ease, until the eyelid returns to its natural shape and the adhesion heals completely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	 Then pour salt water into the eye and wash it with that water, or distill it into the eye using a sieve made from zinc dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	 Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a linen cloth, and place a woolen cloth soaked in egg white over the eye. After three days, use the sieve and bandages until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	 § On the incision of the nail and the excess flesh of the tear ducts.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter 16
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 Know that the nail exists in two forms.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 Either it is nerve-like and resembles a fine, hard sieve, or
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 It is not nerve-like but resembles a frozen, white moisture. When you touch it with an iron tool or try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks off and the hook does not penetrate into it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	 And both types do not appear except from the larger tear duct, which gradually grows until it covers the sight and prevents light and movement of the eye. 》
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the method for operating on it is that the patient should place his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	 Then open his eyes and raise the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	 Then collect the fingernail with a small hook, and extend it towards the top.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	 Then take a needle and insert a horsehair, or cow hair, or goat hair into it; and let the thread be strong, and slightly double the end of the needle, and fix it in the middle of the nail; and pierce it with the needle, and tie the nail with the thread, and extend it towards the top; and strip off the side of the nail that follows the pupil, as if you were pulling it out with the hair until its very end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	 Then cut the remainder in the root of the tear duct with a fine scalpel or with small scissors; and leave the natural tear flesh intact, so that persistent tearing does not occur from the incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	 And sometimes the nail is extended with a hook alone; or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	 Then it should be scraped gently with a scalpel of this form.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	 And be careful that the scalpel does not touch the transparent membrane and cause a break in it, and the pupil be pierced.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Then after the incision, put some crushed salt, or made from sieved sandalwood, into the eye, and leave it until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	 Then care for him with what is needed until he heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	 If the nail is not fleshy and you cannot insert a needle into it nor can a hook be fixed in it, then this type of nail is often cured with medicines, and heals as I have described in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	 If you wish to cut it, then open the patient's eye and take a fine, gentle, weakly sharp scalpel of this form.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	 And scrape the nail from above with subtlety.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	 If you see that it becomes thin and brittle, and a wrinkle imprints on it, then distill into the eye from your hour with sieve made from ziniar, or with red sieve, or with ground salt: and fill the eye until another day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 Then repeat this same procedure until it is all removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	 Unless there is a hot abscess in the eye: then leave it alone and care for the abscess until it heals.
