Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the procedure with wrinkle until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	 If the prominent flesh of the tear duct is causing great harm to the eye, it should be hung with a hook and cut from that part: and do not complete the incision so that the course of tears will not occur.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	 Then distill into the tear duct with a red sieve or one made from ziniar until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	 ¶ On the incision of Alguardenic and flesh formed in the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter Seventeen
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	 Sometimes in certain people's eyes, red flesh forms and covers or almost covers the pupil, or presses on the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outwards; and it resembles a rosebush.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the treatment for this is that the patient should put his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	 Then open the eyes of the patient and collect all that flesh with appropriate hooks; and hold it with one forceps or tweezers. ‍
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	 Then cut the flesh first until all of it is completed with a scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	 And be careful not to harm the eye during the procedure; and your incision should be with what you cut it with, or with a small spatula, as we have said in the incision of the fingernail: or with small forceps, with which asebel is collected, according to its form after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	 And so when your incision is complete and all the white of the eye has been removed, then fill the eye with ground salt or sprinkle red powder and similar things from corrosive medicines onto it; and place a piece of eggshell with its membrane outside the eye to protect it from a hot sty.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	 If some of the white of the eye remains and hot blood prevails in you and you fear a hot abscess, then leave the eye alone and treat it with that which calms the abscess.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the procedure on it until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	 And do likewise with the flesh that happens to be in the eye of this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	 However, it is necessary that those who are treating any weak eye from natural or accidental causes with the knife should not intervene in any of these operations until you see that this member is able to bear that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	 ¶ About collecting pus from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter Eighteen
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	 Pus is red veins that are spread over the eye and prevent vision from functioning properly; they weaken the eye with the passage of time.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	 Therefore, first of all, you must consider whether the eye in which there is pus is strong and has no other disease apart from pus; then collect the pus from it.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And tell the patient to place his head on your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	 Then suspend those veins with one or two hooks according to your skill; and the hook should be thin, made of silver, like this, or there may be two hooks joined together on one body, like this.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	 Then collect those veins with fine scissors carefully and wipe away the blood hour by hour until you see those veins removed from the eye and they are released; and beware of injuring the eye with the tips of the tweezers.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	 And let your operation be in the midday before the sun, and be steadfast in your operation very much: so that you do not cut except those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	 And when you have irrigated, then apply drops to the eye, either green or red, so that with its sharpness it may gnaw away what remains of the stye.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	 But if you are not able to remove all of it in that time, then apply a plaster to the eye with what will soothe the pain of the eye; and leave it for several days, until its pain is quieted: and be sure that it has been freed from the hot stye. Then repeat on it according to the same method, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	 And this is the form of the scissors.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	 About bringing back a deviated septum to the nose.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter Nineteen
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	 Doctors call a deviated septum a fistula, which you should treat with a cautery or with a sharp, burning medicine, as its previous account stated.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	 And if it does not heal, then there is no cure for it, except to incise over the stye at its base and draw out all of the moisture that is in it and the pus, until the opening is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	 Therefore, when the opening has been exposed and you see corruption or blackness within it, then shave it with an instrument whose form is this:
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	 And its name is "cap of roughness.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	 Let it be made of Indian steel, and let its head be round like a needle, which has been marked by the marking of a file or the fine marking of a burnisher; and place it on the corrupted place of bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	 Then turn it between your fingers and press your hand a little until you know that the corruption has been shaved away; and do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	 Then restore the place with drying, styptic medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	 If the place is consolidated and flesh grows there, and the course of pus is cut off: and it remains for forty days, and does not renew, and does not suppurate, and no accident occurs in it: then you should know that it has already healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	 And if not, then there is no skill in it, except to reduce the fistula to the nasal aperture according to this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	 And it is that you expose the bone with an iron instrument or with a sharp medicine; and when the bone is exposed, then take a trepan according to this form, let its tip be triangular of iron: and its handle be a tapered pyramid up to the tip, as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	 Then place it on the bone itself; and let it be near the tear duct; and keep your hand away from the eye a little.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	 Then turn your hand with the trepan, until it penetrates the bone and the patient feels it; through this that he finds air coming out of it when he holds his hand over his nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	 Therefore then restore the place with astringent drying medicines, as I taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	 When flesh grows and the place hardens: then the matter that was discharged to the outside returns to the nose; therefore it is easier on the patient.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	 ¶ On the Reduction of a Swelling of the Eye
Caput XX.	 Chapter 20
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	 When the eye swells completely and there is no harm or diminution of sight: then it is necessary that you release the patient; then bleed him; afterwards place cupping glasses on his neck without scarifying, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	 Then apply to the eye an ointment made from acacia, aloe, frankincense, and sarcocolla.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	 Then bind the eye above with many thin bandages over the plaster.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	 And the method of poultices is: that you take soft cloths, many, and each cloth from them should be folded into four; make many of them. Then place them one on top of another according to the amount the eye needs. Then bind them strongly with a hard cloth.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	 And use fumigations with suction without scarifying.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	 Then remove the fumigation and leave the eye bound day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	 But if the swelling again becomes soft, then it must be bound tightly; then remove the binding after one day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, if you see the eye has returned to its normal state, it is good; and if not, then repeat the application of the poultice, and the binding, and the fumigations, until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	 § On the incision of the eye's tunica.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	 When a break occurs in the eye's tunica, then it protrudes and extends outside the eyelids like a grain of the eye, and it disfigures the person's appearance because of this, and he wishes to cut it off. Then the operation is as I describe: that you insert a needle into the root of the eye from the lower part to the upper part. ‌
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	 Then insert another needle with double thread from the lacrimal part, and make it penetrate; and leave the first needle in its place.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	 Then cut the place of the double thread and tie with it the part of the eye around the needle; and bind it tightly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	 Then remove the needle, and place a wool cloth soaked in egg white on the eye; and leave it until the thread falls with the eye.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	 Then care for the eye with what strengthens it until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	 And sometimes the eye is bound from all sides with a circle of cloth, until the eye adds a large protrusion.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	 Then it should be pierced with a fine probe until it reaches the depth of the eye, and let the moisture of the sclera flow out, and let the eye fall out, and immediately enter; then bind it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	 About the treatment of alcomnatis (a kind of eye disease or disorder).
Caput XXII.	 Chapter 22.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	 This sickness called alcomnatis is nothing but a purulent discharge that accumulates in the eye, similar to water descending from above, and it is not [the eye itself].
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	 And the method for treating this condition is that you should make the sick person sit on a prepared or upright seat.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	 Then take his head with your hands from both sides and move it until you see the pus reach the lower parts of the eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	 Then let it be fixed in place and not move downward, and the light will become clear; and the sick person will see things as he used to see them. And if it does not go downward, know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	 But if the descent of the pus does not occur as we have said, then make the sick person sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	 Then take a fine probe and pierce with it slightly above the thin skin where the conjunctiva meets the corneal layer in the corner of the eye, until the pus comes out. ️
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 When the pus comes out, then drip warm water into the eye in which you have mixed honey; or water in which you have already boiled fenugreek and honey. Then treat it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	 About the treatment of water that has descended into the eye or cataract. ️
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter 23.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	 We have already mentioned the types of water in the division and what applies to piercing according to the explanatory discourse and exposition; then take that same [thing] according to healthiness.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then you should make the sick person sit between your hands, facing the light, near the sun. And bind his healthy eye and tighten it strongly. Then with your right hand, hold closed the eyelid of his left eye (in which is the water), or with your left hand, if the eye in which is the water is the right one.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then take with your right hand almagdah if the eye is left: or with your left hand, if the eye is right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	 Then place the end of the almagdah near the crown in the thickness of the radius where the white of the eye appears, next to the smaller tear duct; then push the almagdah with force, and turn your hand with it until it penetrates the sclera of the eye, and you will feel that the almagdah has reached a hollow place.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	 And the measure of the journey of the almagdah should be deep, as much as the space is from the pupil to the end of the blackness, which is the crown of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	 For you will see these things in the pupil of the eye, because of the clarity of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	 Then place the almagdah up to the point where there is water.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	 Then press it down with one force after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	 If therefore water descends immediately, then the patient sees that thing on which he opens his vision immediately, and the almagdah in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	 Then wait a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	 If water descends again, then remove it a second time, except that the almagdah comes out. xspace
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	 When it is fixed and does not rise again, then remove the almagdah gently; and turn your hand slowly.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	 Then dissolve some clear salt from the mine in water, and wash the inside of the eye with it.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	 Then place outside the eye a piece of wool or cotton soaked in rose oil and egg white, and bind it with the healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	 We, however, and those who are of our time, place on it ground cumin seed mixed with egg white.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	 If the almagdah does not obey you for entry into the eye because of its hardness, since it is made from people whose eyes are very hard, then you should take a spatula called Alberid, which looks like this.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	 Therefore bind it with that very suture, and do not thrust your hand into the opening; there is no need to make a path to the almagda place, but rather make the way subtly.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	 Then insert the almagda, as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	 And at the completion of your work, prepare for the patient a well-made bed in which he may sleep on his back in a darkened house; and let him be kept from all movements and coughing; and give him such food as is gentle to his nature; and let him not turn his head either to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	 And let the bandage remain in place according to its position until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	 Then remove it in that darkened house, and test his sight; and make him look at things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	 Then replace the bandage until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	 And it is not proper to do this at the time of dressing or immediately after the incision; rather one should delay it; because water rises quickly through a strong gaze.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	 But if a hot abscess occurs, then one should remove the bandage before the seventh day; and correct it with that which allays the abscess until it is allayed; then release his sight, and place on his face an oculus to regulate his vision under it for several days, while he remains in the darkened house.  />
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	 Then let him go out of the house gradually, and turn about in his affairs.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	 And know that a student is not excused from looking at it several times; then he may dare to perform the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	 And indeed there has come to us a certain man from those who are of Aleppo, who said that in Aleppo a magda was pierced through which water is sucked up.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	 Truly I have not seen anyone in your land who has done this; nor have I read of it in any of the ancient books; and it is possible that it is new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	 And these are the forms of medicines from honey, so that one who does not know them may stand over them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	 They should be made properly from air, and their ends should be triangular with the same subtlety and sharp.
Formae magda.	 The shapes of honey.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	 ¶ On the care for flesh grown in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter Fourteen.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	 Sometimes fleshy growths of various kinds appear in the nose, among which is something resembling a many-legged scorpion; and from this comes cancerous flesh, stony flesh, dark in color; and from this comes flesh that is soft and not dark in color.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	 In that which is from these fleshes and is soft, not fraudulent or cancerous, you should make the sick person sit between your hands facing away from you; then open his nose and insert a hook into those fleshy growths; afterwards draw them out to the outside and cut off what you have grasped from them with a thin, sharp spatula from one side until you know that all the flesh has been completely removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	 But if any of it remains which cannot be cut off, then scrape that away with a single delicate instrument easily until nothing of it remains.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	 But if there is too much blood or a hot swelling occurs, then apply what is necessary to it; or if it is from malignant swellings, hasten to cauterize it until the bleeding stops and all the fleshy growths are removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	 Then after cutting pour vinegar, water, or wine into the nose.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	 But if the nose is opened and moisture proceeds from it to the palate, then know that he is now cured.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	 But if the moisture does not penetrate as it should, then know that within there is flesh grown on the upper bones of the nose, which the instrument did not reach when cutting.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	 Then you must introduce a linen thread with some thickness and tie many knots in it; put a finger's width or less between each knot. The patient should insert the end of the thread into the nose with a bone splinter or whatever he can, after making it similar to azar. He should pull on his nasal septum until it reaches the cavity and comes out over his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	 And indeed, many times schoolchildren do something similar to this Atom boy; it is an easy thing for one who wants to do it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	 Then place the two ends of the thread; one end that comes out over the nose and the other that remains inside the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	 Then, with the aid of a saw, cut the flesh along with the knots on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	 Do this until you know that the flesh is already with the knots on the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	 Then remove the thread and insert into the nose, after washing off the blood, a linen cloth soaked in Egyptian ointment; do this for three days or more until all the remaining ointment from the flesh is completely dissolved.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 Then at the end of the treatment, insert a lead tube into the nose for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	 If however, dry treatment is needed, use that one.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	 To make a headpiece for distilling oil and other medications into the nose, make it from silver or copper; let it be similar to a small lamp, open like a snail shell, and its channel likewise.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	 And if you wish, make it as a closed tube, like a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	 And the snail-shaped instrument for making a headpiece should be full and open; it should have a handle at its end, with which you hold it when heating oil or anything else you wish from juices and flexible substances in it.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	 And this is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	 ¶ On the care of a nasal polyp.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter 25.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	 Often a polyp appears at the tip of the nose and grows larger with time until it becomes unsightly.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	 And because of this, it is necessary that you cut it out at the beginning of its appearance and remove all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	 Then place on the site either a hot iron or a burning medication which will take its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	 If its cutting is delayed until it grows large, then consider whether it is stony, hard, dark in color, and relatively insensitive: then do not touch it with iron because it is a malignant tumor.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	 For often I have seen someone cut into this type of polyp, and a great evil befell the one who had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	 And if the polyp is soft to touch, not dark in color, and you see that it is possible to cut into all of it, then evacuate the patient and cut it without fear or hesitation: and treat the site with something that dries and constricts until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	 ¶ On suturing the nose, lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 Know that when there is a disruption of continuity in one of these cartilages, surgery is of little benefit except in certain people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, when something like this happens to someone, you should consider if it is a fresh wound with its own blood: then join the lips of the wound with suture: then treat it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	 And if the lips of the disruption have already separated and each part has healed: then it is necessary that you scrape off all the part from its apparent skin until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	 Then join the two lips with suture and tighten them, and sprinkle on it powdered dragon's blood and ground frankincense: and place over the powders a piece of adhesive plaster and another consolidating one: and leave it tied for two days or three.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	 Then dissolve it, and exchange the medicine; and let it go until the threads are cut by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with an ointment, until he is healed.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	 The method of suturing is to join the solution of continuity either with needles, as we have described in the suturing of the belly; or join the solution with a thread, as I have taught you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	 ¶ On the extraction of lip nodes.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter 27.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	 Many people have hard nodes on their lips like grains of barley; some are smaller and others larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	 Therefore, you should turn back the lip and pierce through every node of it, and hang it with a hook, and cut it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then fill the place after cutting with crushed rush-root, until the blood is stopped.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	 Then it should be washed with vinegar, and the place should be scraped with it, until the wounds are healed. 》
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	 ¶ On the incision of flesh on the gum.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter 28.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	 Often there appears over the gums a growth of extra flesh which the ancients call "abulus.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	 Therefore you should hang it with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root, allowing the pus or blood to flow out.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	 Then place crushed rush-root or other hemostatic powders over the site.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	 If that flesh returns after treatment, for it often does return, then cut it a second time and cauterize it; for it will not return after cautery.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	 ¶ On filing teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter 29. 》 》 》
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	 Sometimes on the surfaces of teeth, both inside and outside, and between the gums, rough scabs form, which are ugly; sometimes they turn black, yellow, or green, until that corruption reaches the gum, making the teeth foul-smelling through it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	 It is therefore necessary that you make the patient sit between your hands, and rest their head on your chest. Grind away the enamel and the tooth in which there appear to you cortices and a substance similar to sand: until nothing remains of them. And do likewise with blackness, greenness, yellowness, and other stains until they are cleansed.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	 Therefore, if the cause of what is in them is removed at the beginning of treatment, that is good; and if not, then repeat the treatment on them on another day, a second time, and a third time, until finally your effort achieves what you desire.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	 And know that the tooth requires rasps of various shapes and many forms according to how it is prepared for your operation; because the rasp by which the tooth is scraped from below is different from the rasp by which it is scraped between the teeth, according to other shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	 And let these shapes of rasps be prepared with you, as you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	 § On the Extraction of Toothache
Caput XXX.	 Chapter 30
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	 It is necessary to cure the tooth from its pain with all skill and delay in extracting it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	 For it is not right to remove it when it is extracted, since it is a sublime substance; unless there is no choice but to extract it, then the patient must be forced to extract it so that the painful tooth may be strengthened and confirmed with you.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	 For often the pain deceives the patient and they think it is in the tooth, and so they extract it; then the pain does not go away until the tooth itself is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	 For we have already seen this from the practice of bloodletting physicians.  />
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	 When the painful tooth itself is confirmed with you, then it is necessary to scarify around the tooth with a spatula that has some virtue, until the gum is dissolved from all sides; then move it with your fingers or with fine forceps little by little, until you shake it out.  />  •
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	 Then place large forceps in a good position on it, and hold the patient's head between your knees, which you have already secured well so that it does not move; then pull the tooth straight, so that you do not break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it under the tooth from all sides easily, and try to move it as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	 If the tooth is perforated or decayed, then you should fill that hole with a cloth and tie it tightly with a thin wire so that it does not break when you constrict it with forceps on top of it.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	 And you should carefully perform the scraping around the entire gum very well.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	 And be careful not to break it and leave a piece behind, which would cause the patient more pain than before.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	 And beware of doing what ignorant bloodletters do in their haste and recklessness in removing it, besides giving that which we have mentioned.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	 For they often cause great illnesses to happen to people, whose consequences are more difficult to heal, and all or some of the roots remain, or they extract it with some bones of the jaw, as we have witnessed many times.  />
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	 Then rinse with wine, vinegar, and salt after its removal.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	 If bleeding occurs from the site (for it often happens), then grind some myrobalan and fill the site with it; if not, cauterize the site if myrobalan does not help you.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	 The form of the fine forceps with which the tooth is first moved should have long arms, a short handle, and be thick so that they do not bend when pressed on the tooth; let them be like you see with thick handles, until when you tighten them, they do not give way or bend: with short arms, and let them be made decently from Indian iron, or well-made steel, with straight arms; and in their extremities there should be teeth, some of which fit into others and hold with a decent and strong constriction.  />  />
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	 And sometimes the ends are like the beak of a bird called stork, and they are very tight.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	 On extracting teeth, and removing broken jawbones.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	 When something remains in the extraction of a tooth that is broken, then you should place a cloth soaked with butter over the place for one day or two days until the area softens. Then insert into it algasti or forceps, whose ends resemble the beak of a bird called stork.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	 And this is the shape of the forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	 Their ends should be made like a file inside, or like a small scissor.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	 Therefore, if it does not obey you in exiting with these forceps, then you should hollow out the root and expose all the flesh, and insert a small crowbar, which looks like this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	 Let it be short at the end, somewhat thick; and let it not be wet, so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	 Therefore, if the root exits through it, it is good; and if not, you must help with these other instruments whose shapes are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	 The shape of the first is a triangular end, in which there is some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	 The shape is of a thin triangular end. 》
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	 It is also helped by this instrument which has two branches, and its shape is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	 And with other instruments and tools which have been mentioned in the section on teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	 It is also helped by this instrument which resembles a large hook of this shape, with a twisted triangular end, in which there is some thickness so that it does not break; and let it not be wet. 》 》
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	 And know that there are many instruments of the teeth; and similarly the rest of the instruments are not counted, and a skilled craftsman, who is clever in his art, finds for himself an instrument according to what the operation and the diseases themselves indicate.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	 Because there are diseases for which the ancients did not mention an instrument, due to their diverse types.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	 If, however, a bone is broken from the jaw or other bones of the mouth, or if it becomes putrid, then investigate above it in its place with what suits it from the instruments and tongs that I mentioned for extracting roots, and help with this, whose shape is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	 Let there be something thick in it little by little, so that it may be tied or held with the bone and not flee and go away, until the bone comes out: and restore the place with suitable medicines for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 But if there is a small putrefaction in the bone, then scrape it off from its putrefaction and care for it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	 Concerning the Sawing of Prominent Teeth over Others.
Caput XXXII.	 Chapter XXXII.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	 When teeth prominently project not according to their natural course, an ugly appearance is made by that: and especially when it happens to women and girls, namely sellers of themselves.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	 Therefore, you must consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 For if a tooth is born after another tooth and is not located properly, or its sawing or planing is possible, then extract it: and if it is connected to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument, whose shape is this.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	 It is similar to a small beak and is made of Indian iron, very sharp at its tip.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	 And let your cut with which you cut it be over many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, and so that another tooth is not moved.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	 But if it is exposed to its planing: then plane it with a plane from India, whose shape is this.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	 Let the whole [plane] be from India, and its handle very small, like a plane with which needles are made: with which the tooth is planed little by little over many days easily, so that the tooth is not moved and falls; then anoint it in the end, scrape it with certain scrapers.  ?> Et quod scias hoc est instrumentum quod dicitur bisturi.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	 If it is a tooth that is broken and injures the tongue, then it is necessary to smooth it also, until the roughness of that break is removed and made even: and it flattens out and does not injure the tongue nor corrupt speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	 ¶ On the Extraction of Teeth with Gold Threads.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	 When it happens that the anterior teeth are concussed and shaken by a blow or accident and the patient cannot hold together what he eats so that it does not fall out, and you have treated them with astringent medicines and the cure did not work, then the plan is to tie them with a gold thread because silver turns green and putrefies after a few days, but gold never changes. ¶ When you bind the teeth, make sure to bind from the root of the tooth up to the neck of the tooth, and tie it carefully in the middle so that there is no slack nor is it too tight; take care not to cause any harm to the gum or the neighboring tooth.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	 And let the thread be of moderate fineness and thickness according to the size that fits between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	 And the form of extraction is this: take a thread and insert its double between two healthy teeth; then weave with the two ends of the thread between the moved tooth or teeth, whether one or more, until you reach with the weaving to the other healthy tooth on the opposite side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	 Then repeat the weaving until you reach the part where you began; and hold your hand with fineness and wisdom so that it is not entirely removed; and let your constriction by which you bind the thread be at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not escape. ¶ And when you have completed this binding, you will find that the tooth or teeth are bound up and secured.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	 Then cut the overhanging ends of the thread with scissors; and join both together and turn them with a needle; and hide them between the healthy tooth and the moved tooth, so that they do not injure the tongue; then let it remain tied thus. ¶ And you will find that this binding is a strong aid for the tooth or teeth, so that the patient can chew his food well without difficulty.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	 If it is loosened or cut, tie them with another thread, and they will remain thus throughout the whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	 And this is the form of teeth, and the figure of a healthy tooth and an unhealthy tooth, as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	 And sometimes it happens that a tooth or two return to their places after the incident, and are retained as we have said, and they remain there; and this is done only by an experienced and skilled craftsman.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	 And sometimes a piece from the bones of cows is prepared; and it is made into the shape of a tooth and placed in its place, and the tooth is strengthened and tied as we said; and it remains and serves for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	 ¶ About the cutting of the ligament that occurs under the tongue, which prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter 34
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	 Sometimes this ligament that occurs under the tongue is either natural, which a person is born with, or accidental, from an old wound that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	 And the operation is to open the mouth of the patient while holding their head in your lap, and raise their tongue; then cut through that nerve-like ligament along its width until the tongue is released from its restriction.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	 But if there is something hard and knotted in it, and it comes from an old wound, then insert a hook into it and seek out the width of it until you cut through the ligament and release the knotting.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And be careful not to make a cut too deep into the flesh, lest you cut an artery there and cause bleeding.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	 Then wash the site of the incision with rose water, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	 Then place a linen cloth under the tongue, which the patient should hold every night, so that it does not heal again. 》
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	 If blood flow occurs, then place ground zea on the spot.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 If blood overcomes you, then cauterize the spot with a brunette iron; and then treat it with the other treatment until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	 About the removal of a cyst that forms under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter 35.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	 It sometimes happens that under the tongue a cyst forms, resembling a small frog, hindering the tongue from its natural function; and perhaps it may swell so much that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	 And the treatment of this is to open the sick person's mouth before the sun, and observe the cyst.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	 If you see it to be dark-colored or black and hard, with the sick person feeling no sensation in it, then do not touch it because it is cancerous.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	 And if it is inclined towards whiteness and has moisture, then insert a hook into it and cut it with a thin scalpel, and free it from every part. ︎
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	 If blood overwhelms you during your operation, then place ground zea on it until the bleeding stops; then return to your operation until you remove it with its entirety.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then wash it with vinegar and salt, and treat it with the other appropriate treatment until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	 About the treatment of a cyst in both tonsils.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter 36.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	 It sometimes happens between the throat and gullet, that is, between the tonsils, which resemble almonds; they occur externally and are called two amygdalae. If you treat them with what we said in the previous chapter and they do not heal, then observe.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	 If it is a hard cyst, dark-colored, with little sensation, then do not touch it with iron. ︎ ︎ ︎
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	 And if it is red in color and its root is thick: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing a flow of blood; rather leave it alone until it matures.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	 Then either you will pierce it, or it will burst on its own.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	 And if it is white in color, round, and its root is fine: then it is necessary to cut into it.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 And the operation on it is such that before the operation you should consider if its hot inflammation has quieted with a complete quieting or diminishes by some lessening: then have the sick person sit before the sun and let his head be in your lap; and open his mouth, and let the assistant receive between his hands, and press the tongue downwards with an instrument of this shape.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	 Let it be made of silver or bronze, which is as fine as a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	 When therefore you press with it the tongue, and the inflammation is shown to you, and your sight falls upon it: then take a hook, and fix it in the tonsil, and draw it out as much as you can towards the outside, except that you pull along with it some of the tunic. ()}
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	 Then cut into it with an instrument of this shape which follows.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	 It resembles scissors; but the ends of it should be curved so that the opening of each is opposite to the sharp point of the other; therefore see to it that it is made of Indian steel or another kind which can hold an edge well.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	 If however this instrument is not available, then cut into it with a spatula of this shape.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	 Let it be sharp on one side, and not sharp on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	 And after you have cut into one tonsil, cut into the other in accordance with this same shape of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	 Then after the incision let the sick person gargle with cold water or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If he has a flow of blood, let him gargle with water in which the bark of pomegranates or myrtle leaves have been boiled, and similar stiptics, until the flow of blood is stopped; then care for him until he heals.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	 And sometimes other abscesses arise in the throat besides the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	 Therefore, cut those equally as I said for the incision of the two tonsils.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	 And I myself have already treated a woman for an abscess that had arisen in her throat, which was pulling towards darkness and scarcity of senses, nearly closing her throat; and the woman was breathing from a narrow opening, and it had already prevented her from eating and drinking water; and she had almost reached death if she had remained one day or two.  ()
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	 And the abscess had risen so much that it sent out two branches until they came out through the two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	 I therefore hastened quickly and inserted a hook into one of them.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	 Then I pulled it, and a large piece came out from it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	 Then I cut it off where I held it from the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	 Then I did to him what had come out of the other nostril.  ()
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	 Then I opened his mouth and pressed his tongue; and then I inserted a hook into that abscess; then I cut off part of it, and only a little blood came out from it; the woman's throat was therefore healed, and she immediately began to drink water, and then she took food.  ()  ()
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	 I did not therefore cease to cut from that abscess many times over a long period of time; and the abscess would follow in the place where I had cut, until it became too extended with her.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	 I therefore cauterized the abscess in the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	 He remained from the addition; then I walked away, and I did not know what God did with her after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	 § On the incision of a uvular swelling.
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter 37.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	 When catarrh descends to the throat and swells and is long, it is then called a perpendicular; and if it is thicker and rounder below, it is then called a grape.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	 When it is treated with what we have said about division, and the treatment does not help, and you see that the hot swelling has subsided from it and is thin, then you should cut into it.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	 And if what is gathered from it is round and does not have length, and is red or dark in color, and has no sensation, then you should avoid cutting into it. 
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	 For there is danger for the patient in this.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	 Therefore, when you see it according to the whiteness and its length as I have said, you should make the patient sit facing the sun; and press his tongue with the instrument whose previous description has gone before; then insert a hook into the grape and pull it downward; and cut it with one of the two instruments that I mentioned in the incision of the two tonsils.      
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	 And you should not cut from it, except that which is added above the natural limit without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	 For if you cut more from it, you will harm the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then after the incision, use what we have narrated in the incision of the two tonsils; and care for it until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	 But if the patient is afraid of the incision, then you should use skill in cauterizing it without fear or dread.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 And the method of cautery in it is not, except with boiling water; and it is as if you place the patient's head on your lap.     
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	 Then press his tongue with the instrument we mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	 Then take from the water which I told you about in the chapter on cauterizing, and make an unquenched mortar with it, not thick nor too thin, and fill this hollow of the instrument, whose shape is this.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	 Let its end which holds the medicine be hollowed out like the bowl of a spoon.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	 And place the instrument with the medicine on the same ulcer: and let the patient lie on his side, so that the saliva runs out of his mouth from the internal medicine, so that nothing descends into his throat and harms him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	 Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	 And you apply it to the ulcer for half an hour until you see that it has turned black and that the chewing of the medicine has settled down.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	 And if you wish to use cotton, and wrap it around the end of a spoon, and pour medicine onto the cotton, and insert the spoon with the cotton into the ulcer until the cotton adheres to the ulcer.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	 Do this many times until you achieve what you want from the cauterization of the ulcer.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	 Then leave it alone; for indeed it dries out and falls off after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	 And if you need to repeat the medicine, repeat it: and after cauterization, clean around the ulcer with cotton soaked in butter, and cleanse it with that which is around it from the medicine: and rinse it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	 And let it be scraped externally with plasters, and internally with gargles, until it heals.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	 This method of treatment is therefore healthier than cutting, and more distant from fear.  />
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	 And sometimes the ulcer is also cured with that which is more subtle than cautery and incision; it is cured with fumigation in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	 Gather calamentum, hyssop, oregano, rue, saffron, chamomile, and southernwood, along with similar herbs. Combine them all or some of them in a pot and cover with vinegar. Bring to a boil. The pot should be well-lined with clay, and in the middle there should be an opening over which you place a concave instrument in this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	 It should be made of silver or bronze. Insert the end with the hole into the mouth of the patient until the steam rises through the tube and darkens the throat sufficiently.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	 Then repeat this process many times until dryness occurs.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	 Be careful not to perform this treatment at the onset of inflammation.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	 For it often increases the swelling, and you should not do this except when the heat of the inflammation begins to subside.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	 But if this instrument is not available to you, then take a reed and place at its end the shell of an egg so that the patient's mouth does not get burned. Because the shell of the egg prevents the steam from burning the mouth, and this is a good treatment with health benefits.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	 ¶ On the Extraction of Thorns and Bones from the Throat
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter 38
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	 Often, a bone or a fishbone sticks in the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	 Therefore, you must extract whatever appears, after pressing the tongue with an instrument under bright light and it becomes clear to you what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	 And if something does not appear and is hidden in the throat, you must make the patient vomit before the food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	 For perhaps the thing will come out through the vomit.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	 Or let the patient swallow a piece of nap, or a lettuce root, or a mouthful of dry bread, or take a piece of soft sea sponge and tie it to a thread, then let him swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	 When it reaches the place of the spine or bone and is extracted, then it exits.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	 If therefore it does not exit with what we have said, then use an instrument of lead in this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	 Let it be slightly thicker than a finger and have a curve at its end which he can easily insert into his throat; then let him raise his head upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	 And let him be careful not to touch his epiglottis, lest he should cough and force out bone or spine; or the physician may insert his hand instead.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	 It is truly better that the patient insert it himself because of his knowledge of the place where the object is attached; and let him push downwards or pull up his hand with the instrument until everything comes out according to its size.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	 ¶ On the Extraction of Leeches
Caput XXXIX.	 Chapter XXXIX.
