Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	 When a leech is treated with the remedy mentioned in the division of treatments with medicines and it does not help, then examine the patient's throat in broad daylight or in sunlight after pressing his tongue with the instrument I have described to you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	 If your sight falls upon a leech, extract it with a small hook or with fine tweezers carefully.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	 If it is not possible with them, then take a hollow cannula and insert it into the patient's throat until it reaches close to the throat; then introduce into the cavity of the cannula a red-hot iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	 Do this many times; and let the patient abstain from water for the whole day. ‌
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	 Then let him take a sieve full of cold water and open his mouth into it; and let him rinse his mouth with it, but not swallow any of it; and move the water in one hour after another with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	 The leech indeed immediately falls when it senses water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	 But if it does not come out with what we have described, then fumigate the patient with bedbugs or with a bean using the instrument that I have mentioned for the fumigation of the throat.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	 Do this many times, for she will fall.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	 And the method of operation in fumigation is to take a pot with live coals and fire, and let the pot be covered with a lid, in whose middle there is a hole; and let the end of the instrument be placed in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	 Then pour the fumigation and let the patient put his mouth on the end of the tube, and let him close his mouth so that the fumigation does not escape, until you know that the fumigation has already reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	 For the leech will immediately fall.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	 But if she does not fall, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	 And let the patient endure thirst and eat salted food and garlic, and let him not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	 Therefore it is necessary that she will come out with this regime.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	 And this is the shape of the instrument with which the leech is drawn out from the throat when it falls on its own.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	 It resembles forceps, as you see, except that this curvature is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	 And its end resembles the beak of a bird called a stork, on which there is the roughness of a file; when it grasps something, it does not release it at all. 》
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	 ¶ On the opening and cutting of abscesses, and their general care.
Caput XL.	 Chapter 40
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	 There are many kinds of abscesses and various methods for opening them, according to the memory that comes to us in this book, namely one kind and one in particular; and there are two ways of perforating and cutting them. 》 》 》
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	 One is of the species of a tumor within itself, and because it includes moisture.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	 And the second method is due to the places where it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	 Since a tumor occurring in the head is different from one occurring in the anus; and a tumor occurring in a fleshy place is different from one occurring in joints; and each has its own judgment based on its position.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	 And among tumors there are those which should not be pierced except after the pus in them has matured and completed; and there are some which should be pierced while they are fresh and do not ripen according to their completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	 Like tumors which are near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	 Since a tumor when it occurs near a joint and its duration is prolonged until what surrounds it putrefies perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are destroyed; therefore it is a closer cause of the contraction of that member.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	 Or the tumor is in a main limb; since if you delay its piercing until it matures, it will harm either that [limb], or through that main limb [the whole body].
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	 Or it is near the anus; therefore pierce it while it is immature, and you should not pierce a fresh tumor which has not completed its digestion, except that which is near the anus, so that it does not putrefy deeply and extend to the interior of the anus and become a fistula, or end in a place that does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	 You should know the time for piercing a tumor which has matured according to its completion; and it is at the cessation of pain, the subsiding of fever, and the diminution of redness, pulsation, and sharpness of the head of the tumor, and other signs.  />
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	 And you should make the same perforation in the lower part of the tumor and its more prominent area; and let the piercing be along the length of the body if the tumors are in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of arms, strings, nerves, arteries, and finally in all equal places where there is no reflection.  />   
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	 In those [conditions] that reflect, go with a perforation along that membrane.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	 When the abscess is in fleshy areas, it is better to leave its perforation until its digestion is consolidated, as we have said at the conclusion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	 For if you perforate it before that, the course of the virus is prolonged from it, and there is much dirt and foulness, and perhaps its lips harden and its depth [becomes] affected.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	 And some abscesses are perforated according to the width of the body by necessity, or according to what that member needs.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	 And you should administer a small perforation for small abscesses and a large perforation for large abscesses, or many sections according to the size of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	 And there are abscesses in which it is necessary to concave the skin and cut when it has become like a cloth, and it has reached its end, that is, it is already dead, as happens with many ulcers and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	 And among them are those which are cut with a three-cornered incision.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	 And among them is one which is cut like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	 Like an inguinal abscess.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	 And among them are those in which a round section and a crescent-shaped section, and similar ones from the sections, are administered.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	 However, that which does not have a head, such as are the mild and superficial abscesses, you should perforate it with a superficial or flat perforation only.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	 And when the abscess is thick and has already collected much pus, and you perforate it, do not hasten to extract all the pus at that hour; rather, extract a part of it from it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	 Then prepare the abscess until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	 Then extract something from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	 Do this many times according to the condition, until it comes out: especially if the patient is weak or a pregnant woman, or a small child, or an old decrepit person; for the vital spirit of the living creature is often released from the body with the discharge of pus, and perhaps the sick person will die, and you won't notice.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	 Therefore, beware of this chapter with great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	 And after your perforation, by which you pierce these abscesses, it is necessary to clean the wound: and observe.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	 If therefore the abscess is small or the incision is flat, then apply a compress of flax or old cotton.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	 And if the abscess is large and the incisions are many, it is then necessary to insert a compress into each incision until they meet each other.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	 And if in the abscess you have cut off a piece of skin or hollowed it out: then it is necessary to fill it with old cotton, or as when making felt, or shaving flax down without moisture: and bind it tightly until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then remove it, and care for it with what is necessary from the ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	 But if bleeding occurs during your procedure, then apply cold water and vinegar, after the cloth has been soaked in them: and place it on the site of the bleeding many times. />
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	 But if the bleeding persists, then it is necessary to administer a regimen and treatment and powders, which I have described in many places of this book of ours, and from the division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	 But if it is during the winter season and the site of the abscess has many nerves, then you should pour hot powders with wine and oil onto it: and place them on the sites.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	 And if it is in the summer and the places are fleshy; then you must place little poultices soaked in water and oil, or with wine and oil, and all of that cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	 Until the third day, as we have said, then you must release the abscess and clean it, and administer to its healing what is suitable for it, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	 Therefore, this is necessary from the knowledge of treating abscesses universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	 According to half of the distinction, I have already spoken about every abscess and how there is a way to treat it individually by chapter.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	 ¶ On the incision of abscesses that occur on the scalp.
Caput XLI.	 Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	 Little abscesses occur on the scalp, and they are of the species of nodules, which are enclosed by sheaths, like those of hens' eggs.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	 And their species are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	 Some of them are fatty; and some contain a moisture like clay; and some contain a moisture similar to gruels or poultices; and others similar to these, and there are those which are hard as stone.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	 And in the incision of all of them and their extraction there is no danger, as long as during their incision a blood vessel does not cause resistance.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	 And the operation of their incision is to examine them with an instrument, the shape of which will come after this, called Introducer, until you know what they contain.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	 For if it contains moisture, then cut it with a section along its length with a superficial section; in this manner. 》
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	 And begin with the section from line b to line g. When therefore the moisture is evacuated, then remove the skin that contains that moisture, and do not leave anything of it. 》 》
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	 Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Often it returns if something of it remains.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	 For it [the kist] indeed eats away what remains from the kist.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then anoint the cotton a second and third time with the Egyptian [unguent], and if you need to, continue doing so until you are confident that nothing remains of the kist; then treat the wound with ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	 If the aposteme contains a fatty tumor, then cut it according to this shape, with an incision forming a cross: and throw the hooks between the lips of the incision, and strip it from all sides: and strive to extract the membrane that encloses it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	 But if a contrary reaction is caused by the blood vessel, then do what I will tell you later.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	 And likewise do this for an aposteme if it is stony, with the same incision and treatment as we have said.  />
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	 And the incision on a stony aposteme is easier because it has little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	 And sometimes there are certain of these apostemes which are on the head in some men, and with which there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	 That is to say, for I cut into an aposteme on the head of an old woman and found the aposteme like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if someone hit it with something thrown at it, it wounded [the person].  />  />
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	 In other apostemes that occur on the head, however, apart from these apostemes that occur on the heads of children and at the roots of the ears, let the incision of all of them be a surface incision.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	 Or make their perforations always from below them, so that the flow of pus will be relieved towards the lower [part].  />  />
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	 Then care for them with what is suitable for their treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	 Of cutting the tonsils in the neck.
Caput XLII.	 Chapter XLII.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	 These abscesses often occur in the neck, under the armpits, and in the groins; and sometimes they occur elsewhere in the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	 And concerning those which occur in the neck, there is one and many; and they generate each other; and every tonsil among them is within its own proper tunic, just as it is with nodes and abscesses of the head, as we have said.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	 And there are many types of these tonsils.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	 For some of them are stony; and among them there are those which contain moisture; and among them there are malignant ones, which do not obey treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	 Therefore, when you see one of them which has a good disposition and texture, whose color is close to that of the skin, and it moves in all directions, and it is not connected with the nerves of the neck, or with the vein, or with the artery, and it is not deep; you should cut it out by means of a superficial incision from top to bottom along line b-g, and scrape it off from every side; and spread apart the two lips of the skin with a hook or with many hooks if you need them, as we have said about the abscesses of the head, and extract it little by little.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	 And it is important to be careful not to cut a vein or nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	 And let the knife not be very sharp, so that it does not make your hand hesitate with the cutting, or disturb the patient, and you do not cut what is not necessary. ›
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	 But if you cut a vein or artery, and it hinders you from performing the operation, then place in the wound ground zegi, or certain powders which stop bleeding, and bind up the wound, and leave it alone until the inflammation subsides and the wound becomes soft; or begin and it wants to putrefy. › ›
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	 "For blood is severed by the skin, return therefore to your work until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	 Then inquire with your index finger whether there remains anything from the other small strophulae; therefore cut them and clean them out.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	 But if there is a large vein at the root of the strophula, then you ought not to cut that strophula from its root; rather, you should tie it off with strong doubled thread and leave it until it falls off by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	 Then fill the wound with old cotton which you have already soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	 Then care for him.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	 If the entire strophula is cut off, then you should approximate the two lips of the wound and sew it up immediately after you see that there is no remaining pus.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	 But if you see that there is remaining pus because of the largeness of the strophula, then you should intend to cut off its root and pull it out; and apply the stitching which we have mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	 And for those strophulae which contain humors, make a superficial puncture in them so that you may see their stage of maturity; and make the puncture from below the body as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	 Then apply lint with ointment and similar things after the puncture, so that it may eat away what remains of the corruption, until you see the wound has been cleansed; then care for him with regenerative flesh ointment until he is healed.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	 § On the incision of the epiglottis due to an abscess occurring within the throat.
Caput XLIII.	 Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	 The ancients said that this incision is made on the epiglottis, and I have not seen anyone in our land who has done it; and here is their explanation of it. ›
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	 In those with a stricture, the incision of the epiglottis should be avoided because it will not bring benefit; all the veins and lungs are weakened.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	 In those with a hot abscess in the mouth, throat, or both tonsils, and there is no illness in the intestine, the epiglottis should be incised to avoid the destruction that occurs from choking.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	 Therefore, when we wish to do this, we should incise the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis with a small incision by width, in that which is between two circles by quantity, so that the incision is in the cartilage, not in the cartilage: and this place is suitable for incision because it is devoid of flesh, and the blood vessels from it are distant.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	 If the surgeon is timid, then he should stretch the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	 Then let him pierce the skin until it reaches the canal; he should avoid the blood vessel if he sees any of them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	 Then let him cut the cartilage as we have said; it is indicated by the suppuration that comes out of the canal along with its breaking and the loss of voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	 And leave the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	 Therefore, when the time comes that choking is feared, gather together the two lips of the skin wound and suture it alone without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	 Then apply treatments that cause flesh to grow until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	 Albucasis said this.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	 The summary of this discussion that we have narrated is not applicable except when they see that one of these abscesses has already choked the patient's throat and the patient is close to death and wishes to be incised; they go to cut the epiglottis so that the patient can breathe over the wound for a certain breath and be saved from death. And for this reason, they commanded leaving the wound open until the malice of the illness is consumed, and its malice lasts three days or thereabouts; then they commanded suturing the wound and treating it until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	 And what I have seen with my own eyes is that a maidservant took a knife and thrust it into her throat, cutting through part of the lung's canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	 And I was called to treat her, and found her moaning like a dying person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	 Therefore, I opened the wound and found that blood had come out from it only in small amounts.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	 Therefore, I was confident that she had not cut a vein or an artery; and air was coming out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	 I hastened to sew up the wound and treat it until it was healed; nothing happened to the maidservant except for a hoarseness in her voice, and after some days she returned to better health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	 Therefore I say: that there is no fear in cutting the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	 ¶ On cutting a hernia of the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	 Chapter Forty-Four.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	 This tumor is called a hernia of the throat; it is a large tumor similar to the color of the body and is common among women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	 And there are two types: either it is natural or it is acquired.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	 Certainly, the natural one has no cleverness.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	 The acquired type, however, is of two kinds; one resembles fatty nodes.  ·
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	 And the other type is similar to the tumor that results from a knotting of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	 And in this case, there is danger; one should not assume to cut it with a knife unless it is small. Test it and examine it with an intromitter.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	 Therefore, if you find it to be like a fatty node and not connected to any veins, then cut it as one would cut a node; and remove it along with the sac containing it, if there is a sac; and if not, then explore its entirety.  ·  ·  ·  ·  ·  ·
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then treat the place with what is needed for healing until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	 On the cutting of superficial tumors.
Caput XLV.	 Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	 There are many kinds of tumors, and I have already described all their types in the division: and it is necessary that I now tell here the difference between a tumor and an abscess, since this causes doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	 I say therefore that when it is an abscess, there is heat, fever, and severe pain until the ebullition of the superfluity is calmed and the putrefaction is completed; then indeed the fever and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	 But in a tumor, there is no heat, nor fever, nor pain; and they contain kistis ifachin, which is their own bag, and it is according to the color of the body: and their beginning is like a chickpea, and it becomes like bathecha, either larger or smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	 And there are two kinds of them: either fatty, or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	 The colors of the moisture are many, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	 Therefore, when you come to the healing of a tumor, you must examine it and investigate its contents first with an instrument called a probe, as its form will be shown in the chapter that follows this one.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	 And the way to investigate all tumors and swellings is as follows: take this instrument and insert it into the moistest part of the tumor which you find; then turn your fingers with it gradually until you know that the instrument has already penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	 Then place your hand behind according to the size of the swelling.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	 Then remove the probe and examine what exits in its wake.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	 If a running moisture emerges from it, whatever its color may be, then incise it with a superficial cut, as I said in the case of other swellings.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	 And if the moisture does not exit the wound after insertion, then know that it is fatty. Cut above it with a cross-shaped incision as I have taught you: and hang it with hooks, and remove the skin from all sides easily: and keep kistin over it, if you can, to extract it whole with the knot.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	 But if the bag bursts during the procedure and it is not possible to extract it whole (for this often happens), then extract it piece by piece until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	 For if some little or much remains, the knot will return in great quantity.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 But if you are overcome and something remains: then at the end of your procedure fill the wound with some sharp corrosive powders; and close the wound, and place a warm compress on it, and care for it along with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	 Therefore if the knot is large, then either its two lips, and care for it with that which causes healing.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	 But if the pulsating vein is against you or not pulsating: then hurry and fill the zegi place with ground powder, and leave it tightly bound for two days or three until the wound putrefies and the boiling of the blood subsides; then return to cut that which remains from the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	 ¶ About external instruments for cutting and perforating.
Caput XLVI.	 Chapter 46
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	 Among them are the forms of intromittal instruments, and they are of three types.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	 For among them is a large one, and among them is a medium one, and among them is a small one. ︎︎
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	 They should be made of square-ended steel with neatly trimmed edges to hasten entry into the abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	 And these are the forms of the instruments for probing and puncturing, that is, the piercers; one of them is called beris, that is, the piercer; and there are three types of them.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	 Of these there is a large one, and a medium one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	 They are used to investigate aposteme, issue, fistula, and buboes from the bone between them.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	 Others are made round, smooth, and soft, like large needles with which to stitch seats, of citron wood, or copper, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	 And the best of them are those made from citron wood.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	 And experience has also been gained from black lead [graphite], which is suitable to investigate fistulas that have recesses, so that it can glide with them gently into the recesses.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	 And they are again of three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	 Because from them there are long ones, and medium-length ones, and short ones, according to the width of the fistula and its constriction.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	 The shape of hooks is diverse and of many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	 Because from them there are simple ones, that is, those which have one curvature; and they are of three kinds as you see, large, medium, and small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	 And among them are blind hooks; and they are of three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	 And among them are hooks having two curvatures, and they are of three kinds; and among them are hooks having three curvatures, and they are of three kinds; and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	 And these are the forms of scalpels, with which nodes and aposteme are cut and scraped; and they are of three kinds, because from them there is a large one, a medium one, and a small one.  \\
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	 Their tips with which the cutting is done are sharp, the other tips are not sharp; and they are not placed thus except to be of help in scraping nodes when there is fear of cutting a vein or nerve, and so that the sick person may heal through them and find some relief for a while from the burning sensation that is found in scraping an aposteme.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	 These are magdala, and they are among the three spices.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	 It is made from copper and resembles a ray [of light], with which it makes alcohol: and at its broad end there are hidden small perforations: and through them it runs to the interior and to the exterior when you wish, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	 The shape of the hidden spatulas that are between the fingers at the perforation of the fistulae: and the sick person does not feel them; and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	 The forms of the ventuses with which the flow of blood is cut off: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	 They are made from copper or brass, round, slightly elongated, as you see: and they should be very thin.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	 And you should have these large and small kinds of ventuses with you: so that you may quickly cut off the blood through them when necessary, and then when there is no medicine at hand.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	 However, you should not use them to cut off blood in every part of the body, and you should only use them on fleshy parts: such as the thighs of the legs, and the hips, and the arms of the upper limbs, and the breasts, and the belly, and the groin, and similar fleshy, moist parts.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	 And sometimes they are made into small other instruments similar to the peels of figs, according to their shape: with which blood is cut off when it flows from a place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of a vein, or an artery: and sometimes they are made round according to this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	 ¶ Concerning the treatment of human breasts that resemble female breasts.
Caput XLVII.	 Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	 Sometimes the breasts of certain men swell at the end of sleep (that is, when they begin to sweat during sleep) until they resemble female breasts: and they remain unpleasantly inflamed.  /> ¶ De cura eorum.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	 He who abhors that should cut above the breasts with a crescent-shaped incision, according to this form from the line b to the line g. Then remove all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	 Then fill the wound with healing ointment.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then join the two lips of the wound together with a stitch and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	 If the breast falls downwards and softens because of its size, as happens with women, then two crescent-shaped incisions should be made on both sides of it, each one meeting at the end with the other, so that the larger line encloses the smaller one, according to this form from line b to line g. Then remove the skin between the two lips and take away the fat, and administer what we said about the stitch and powders, which are necessary for healing, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	 But if you cannot complete the incision that you should make because of the restlessness of the patient or due to bleeding, then you should fill the wound with a cloth soaked in caustic ointment and leave it until it corrodes away the remaining fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him until he heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	 ¶ On the perforation of an abscess that occurs under the nipple.
Caput XLVIII.	 Chapter XLVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	 These abscesses that occur under the nipple are of the hard variety of tumors, which contain cysts, and among them are those which contain fluids.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Therefore, those which contain fluids should be cut with a crescent-shaped incision, according to this form from line b to line g. When everything in the abscess has been evacuated as pus, then fill it with an old cloth and leave it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then the bandage is removed and it is treated with a suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	 If the abscess is of the kind called "Strophuli" knots, then cut over it as we said for cutting over Strophuli equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	 But if the wound spreads to the point of discharging pus, then apply a hot iron to it as we have said previously.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	 On cutting an abscess that occurs because of an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	 Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	 When an artery bursts and the skin above it heals, then often an abscess occurs from there; and similarly this happens with veins, so that an abscess and swelling occur in them.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	 And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and swelling are because of an artery or vein are: because when the abscess is from an artery, it is long, deep within the body; and when you press on the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there is a crackling sound. ➤
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	 And that which is from a vein is round and visible on the body's surface.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	 And cutting over this abscess is a mistake, especially if it is under the armpits, groins, neck, and in many places of the body; and it is very serious.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	 Therefore, its treatment with a knife should be avoided, and that which is also at the extremities or on the head should also be avoided.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	 Therefore, over what comes from them from an inflammation of the artery opening, find a cut in the skin lengthwise.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	 Then open the cut with hooks, afterwards the artery; and free it from its coatings until it is laid bare.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	 Then introduce a needle under it and make it penetrate to the other side; and tie off the artery with double thread at two places, as I taught you for extracting two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	 Then prick the place that is between the two ligaments with a lancet, until all the blood comes out and the abscess is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then administer a treatment that produces pus, until the ligaments fall off; afterwards treat it with suitable ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	 If the abscess is due to a cut vein, then you must hold with your hand what you can from the abscess along with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	 Then insert a needle under the place that you held with your hand, and make it penetrate through; and let there be a double thread in it, until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	 Then tie it together with the abscess using a good ligature, as I have told you for a grape ligature, from two sides with two ends of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	 But if you fear that the thread might be pulled out, then insert another needle with another thread under the whole abscess near the incision of the needle; press down and tie your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	 Then cut the abscess in its middle, until what is inside comes out; then cut away the excess skin and leave what was tied from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	 Then place on it a little wool that you have soaked in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then administer a treatment made with bandages and ointments, until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	 ¶ About the abscess that occurs from the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	 Chapter L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	 As an abscess can occur in arteries and veins, so too it can occur in nerves; this occurs in them from a blow or from excessive labor and the like. And it happens most frequently in the joints of the fingers or toes, and in every place where the joints move; and it is a severe abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	 It resembles the color of the rest of the body and is usually painless. However, when it is strongly constricted, the patient feels a numbness similar to that caused by cold.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	 And there is no abscess formed deep within the body, but rather under the skin, and it can be moved in all directions, neither advancing forward nor backward.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	 Therefore, if this condition is in the joints, it should not be cut open with a knife.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	 For perhaps contraction may occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	 But if it is on the head or forehead, incise the skin with a scalpel.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	 If, therefore, the abscess is small, then hold it with forceps and cut it off at its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 And if it is large, then hang it with a hook and peel it off; then remove it and close the wound with stitches; and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	 ¶ On incising an abscess that occurs in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	 Chapter LI
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	 It happens to some people very often in their bellies and in other parts of their bodies that there form little swellings which are called fungal tumors because they resemble mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	 Whose root is thin and whose head is thick, and the lips of these tumors are turned inside out.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	 And there are small ones among them; and there are some that grow very large.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	 And I myself have seen a man who had two of these tumors in his belly, and they were more like mushrooms than anything else; there was no difference between them - they were white, with small roots, and the lips of both turned inside out, and they oozed, and moisture always ran from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	 I then incised them and found that one weighed about eight ounces and the other six ounces. And the operation for incising them is as follows: if the patient is moist and the tumor is white, soft, with a thin root, then incise it with a broad scalpel and have cauteries ready in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	 Often indeed much blood is expelled at its section; therefore hasten if you are overcome by blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	 But if you see the patient is fearful and timid about incision with a blade, then take a well-made leaden thread and tie it around the mole: its method is as we have said, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	 Then add to the constriction of the lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	 Therefore do not cease to tie the lead, whenever it presses on the mole, until it is cut off and falls away by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	 But if the mole is of a large root, then there is something fearful and dreadful about its incision, especially that which is in the abdomen.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	 Nevertheless, it is possible for you to incise half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	 Then cauterize it, so that it does not return.  />
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	 Then treat it until the wound heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	 And beware of presuming to incise a mole that is black in color, has little sensation, and is ugly in appearance; for it is a cancerous abscess, and I will discuss Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	 § On the treatment of umbilical hernia.
Caput LII.	 Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	 Umbilical hernia occurs for many reasons.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	 Or from the fissures that are above the abdomen; and an altheb or intestine protrudes from it, just as occurs in other hernias.  />  />
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	 Or from blood that flows out of a vein or artery, as has been stated above.  />  />  />  •
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	 Or from constriction of the bowel at that point.  />  •  />
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	 But if it is due to a fissure of the peritoneum and protrusion of fatty tissue, then its color resembles that of the body; it is soft, without pain, and appears in various forms.  />  •  />  />  •  />  >
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	 And if it is due to the evacuation of the intestine, then its condition is, along with what we have narrated, more severe in its diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	 When you press it with your fingers, it hides; then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it: and it becomes very prominent at the entrance to the bath, and causes great labor.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	 If, however, it is due to moisture, it is mild; then it does not hide when you press it with your hand, nor does it constrict, nor does it increase.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	 If it is due to blood, then along with these signs an abscess appears in the form of a blackish swelling.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	 But if it is due to rotting flesh, then the abscess is heavy, large, hard, and settles in one place.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	 If, however, it is due to gaseousness, then its touch is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	 And the treatment in that case is that you should then consider whether the swelling of the navel is due to blood from an artery or vein, or gaseousness; then it is necessary for you to refrain from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	 For there is danger and fear in that, as I have taught you in the chapter where I spoke about abscesses due to an artery or vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	 But if the swelling of the navel is due to the intestine or bladder, then you must instruct the patient to hold his breath and stand upright and extended.  />   If you do not do this, he will die quickly, as I have informed you in the preceding chapter about a patient who died because he did not hold his breath.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	 Then mark the signs around the entire circumference of the navel with cautery.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	 After that, tell him to turn over onto his back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	 Then surround with a wide spatula the place around the navel where you marked with cautery.  />   After that, tell him to turn over onto his stomach between your hands.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	 Then extend the middle of the abscess upward with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	 Then bind it around firmly with thread or strong silk cord; let the knot of the binding be loose.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	 Then open the middle of the abscess extended above the bandage.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	 If you find that it has already been caught by the bandage, then pull out the loose part and insert your index finger into it; push the intestine back into the abdomen. And if you find a hernia, then take hold of it with the hook and cut off its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	 But if an artery or vein is opposite to you, then circle around it often.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	 Then return to your task.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	 Take two needles and thread two strong threads on them; then introduce the two needles into the circle you have made around the abscess in the form of a cross, making them penetrate through.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	 Then bind the abscess in four places above the needles; and if you wish, remove the needles and leave it alone until the extended flesh putrefies and falls away by itself; or cut it when it softens and putrefies.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with the necessary ointments until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	 But if the protuberance of the navel is due to fleshiness or moisture, then it is necessary that you make a concave incision in the abscess, as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	 And extract the blood or moisture that you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	 Then treat it with what strengthens the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	 ¶ On the treatment of CANCER.
Caput LIII.	 Chapter 53.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	 We have already spoken in the classification of the kinds of cancer and how to approach its treatment with medicines; and one must be careful in its treatment with iron, so that it does not ulcerate. And we have spoken about cancer generated in the womb and the caution in its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	 And the ancients said that sometimes cancer is in a place where it is possible to remove it: such as cancer of the breast or thigh, and similar places, from the limbs for removing all of it; especially when it is small and beginning.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	 But if it has become chronic and is large, you should not approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	 For I have not been able to cure anyone from it; nor did I ever see anyone before me who reached that [stage].
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	 And the operation on it, when located as we have said, is that you precede it and dissolve the patient with black bile frequently.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	 Then bloodletting of the patient if a young man with obvious congestion.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	 Then prepare the patient for preparation, in which he is located during the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	 Then cast hooks into the cancer that fit it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	 Then hollow it out from every side with the skin, according to the examination, until nothing remains of its roots: and let the blood run, and do not cut it quickly, but press on the places, and wipe away all the thick blood with your hand or with whatever is possible there among the instruments.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 But if the flow of thick blood from the cutting of an artery or vein gives you trouble, then cauterize the vein until the blood is cut off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with the remaining treatment, until he heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	 § On treating dropsy.
Caput LIIII.	 Chapter 45.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	 We have already narrated in the division of the types of dropsy, and how the water accumulates; and the signs of each type, and its treatment with medicines. 》
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	 And that which is treated with iron is only the sole type of ascites; and the type of tympanites is not approached with iron, nor the type of hypochondriac dropsy at all; for that is fatal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	 When you have treated this species of hydrocephalus with medicines and your treatment has not helped, then consider
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	 For if the patient has already become weak, or there is another disease with him besides hydrocephalus, such as coughing, or loosening of the bowels, and similar things, then be careful not to treat him with iron, for it is dangerous.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	 But if you see that the patient is of strong constitution and there is no other disease with him except hydrocephalus alone, and he is neither a boy nor an old man, then the manner of operating on him is as follows: You raise the patient standing between your hands, and an assistant behind him presses his abdomen with his hand, forcing the water down to the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	 Then take a thorny sponge, in this manner.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	 It should be of two sharp points, long, with a sharp end like a little sponge.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	 However, there should be something of gradual narrowness in it, so that you do not penetrate with it during the operation all the way to the intestine and injure it.
Deinde considera.	 Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	 For if the hydrocephalus is generated from the part of the intestines, then you must extend the cut with a section from the navel for the length of three fingers, downwards directly above the chest.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	 But if the hydrocephalus is generated on account of liver disease, then your cut should be to the left of the navel by three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	 And if its origin is on account of the spleen, then let the cut be on the right side; and it should not even be on the side where the patient wishes to lie, so that the superfluities do not run to that weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	 Then pierce the whole skin with the instrument.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	 Then introduce the sponge into that section, and lift your hand with the sponge under the skin, as if you are removing it; and let the amount that is removed be the size of a nail or about that.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	 Then pierce the tissues until you reach an empty space, which is a place of water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	 Then extract it and insert this tool into the opening, whose shape is as follows.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	 And it is similar to a tube; it is made of silver, bronze, or brass, smooth and polished. At its lower end there is a small opening, and on its sides there are three openings, two on one side and one on the other. And the tip of it is cut in the manner of cutting a reed, as you see; at its upper end there is a ring.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	 For when the tool reaches the water, then the fluid immediately rises over the tool; therefore, draw out of the water half a measure's quantity per hour.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	 Because if you draw out of it more than is necessary, the patient may die within the hour through the dissipation of his vital spirit; or he may fall into a swoon that approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	 Truly, draw out of it according to the strength of it and according to what the condition of the patient indicates to you from the strength of his pulse and from its goodness.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	 Then remove the tool and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	 That is, because it is immediately retained due to the skin which retains the opening that is above the tissue; about which I have told you to pierce it in that manner.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	 Then repeat the procedure with the tool on the following day, if you see the patient tolerating it; and draw out from the water also a small quantity.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	 Do this for several days without fear, and guard yourself against error; until there remains from the water only a little.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.
