Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	 Let its arch be above, its sharpness from iron, and its handle from boxwood, and let it be made neatly in a pyramidal shape.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	 The shape of the razor for cutting tendons.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	 Let the head of this razor be in the shape of a star-shaped nail head, and its points be in the shape of the points of the elischetefeg.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	 And it is not suitable except to scrape with it the heads of tendons when they are damaged or have a large and wide opening.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	 The shape of the larger razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	 The shape of the medium-sized razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	 The shape of the wide razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	 The shape of the razor with a concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	 The shape of another fine razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	 The shape of another curved-tipped razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	 The shape of a small and delicate probe.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	 The shape of the razor with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	 Also, the shape of the large razor. xspace
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	 This resembles a file and its tip is like a saw; it is used in many places because of the roughness of the bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	 The shape of the razor suitable for scraping that which has been perforated from the bone.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 Its tip is triangular, with sharp points.
Fit ex Indi.	 It comes from India. xspace
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	 And similarly, it is necessary that all of the things which we have mentioned be made from razors and chisels and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	 ¶ On cutting off extremities and sawing bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	 Chapter Eighty-Nine
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	 Extremities become putrid either from an external cause or from an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	 When you have treated that corruption with medicinal treatment and the treatment does not help, and you see the corruption spreading in the extremity where nothing heals it, then you must cut off that limb until the point of corruption, so that the sick person may escape from death or from a greater evil due to the loss of the limb.  />
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	 And the sign of which this occurs is that the member turns black until it seems rotten; that fire has burned it, or that it becomes rotten after turning black; until that rot extends to the next member and spreads throughout the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	 Hurry therefore with its incision, and likewise if the cause of the rotting is from the bite of certain venomous creatures, such as a sea scorpion, a viper, a toad, and similar things.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	 If therefore the rotting or bite is at the tip of a finger, then cut the finger and do not leave space for the rotting to advance up to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	 And likewise if it occurs on the hand, then cut it from the root of the finger, and do not leave space for the rotting until it reaches into the flesh of the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	 And if it invades there, then cut the arm at the elbow in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	 But if the rotting passes through and you see it around the elbow, then death is certain for the patient.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	 And to administer something beyond that from the treatment is a measure of skill.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	 And do the same for the foot when rotting invades a toe; then cut it at one of the joints. And if it reaches to the sole of the foot, then cut off the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	 But if it goes up to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	 If rotting has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill in it except to release and leave the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	 And the method of cutting a member or sawing it is to tie a ligature below where you wish to cut, and tie another ligature above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	 And one assistant should pull the lower ligature downward, and another assistant should pull the upper ligature upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	 And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligatures with a broad spatula until all of the flesh is revealed. 
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	 Then it should be cut or cauterized.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	 And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth from all parts and that the saw does not touch the healthy place: and an additional injury may occur to the patient, as well as a hot abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	 But if bleeding occurs inside while you are working, then quickly cauterize the place or put on it some powders that absorb blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	 Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable bandage and take care of it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	 And I tell you that this same thing happened to a man on his foot, just as I am telling you now.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	 Which means that blackness occurred on his foot with a burn that resembles the burning of fire: and this corruption first appeared on his toe until it began to affect the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	 Therefore, the man hastened to remove it himself after he saw the corruption attacking his limb with great intensity, as he found from the pain and burn: and he cut into himself at the joint, and was cured.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	 And after a long time had passed, that same corruption occurred on his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	 Therefore he came to me, and I tried to remove that excess with what I placed on his hand from medicines after cleaning his body: but the excess did not go away, and it began to advance into another finger until corruption began in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	 So he called on me to cut open his hand: and I did not want to do that, hoping that through my means the excess would be removed: and I also feared that cutting into his hand could cause death.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	 Because the strength of the man was against this situation.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	 After he despaired of me, he returned to his land: and word came to me about him that he had hastened and cut open his whole hand: and he was cured. 》
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	 And I have not brought forth this account except to serve as an aid regarding that which falls under the category of this disease; and so that there may be a signification by which it is indicated, and according to which action should be taken.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	 About the care of veins and the quality of enema with medicines.
Caput XC.	 Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	 When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy limbs and the abscess extends to the point of forming a collection of pus: then it bursts or is perforated, and what is inside it, namely pus, comes out; and there remains a space empty as if it were a vessel; and the skin over it is like a thin cloth that has not yet reached the final stage of decay, neither does it press upon an opening, nor upon a nerve, nor upon a ligament: then it deserves to be called a Sinus; and it is not called a Fistula. However, if its space extends to the point where corruption presses upon any one of these parts, then it is called a Fistula or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	 And its treatment is that you should cut all that skin as if it were rolled back; and especially when it has become thin like a cloth; and trusting that it will not adhere to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	 But if you hope that the skin will adhere and that the final corruption will not follow; and if there is a thickness of flesh in the skin, then treat it with an enema: and it should be treated as if it were a Sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	 Then if it is large and the pus that comes out of it has a foul odor, then enema it with an Egyptian medicine made of vinegar, oil, and gum acacia, the parts being equal, collected in a vessel; and they are cooked over fire until the medicine becomes red; and it reaches the consistency of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Then take from it what you need, and dissolve it with water and honey, and administer it as an enema to the bladder. Close its opening and leave the medicine inside for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Then extract it with pressing. Do this for so many days until the bladder is cleansed and the odor removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And sometimes it should be administered as an enema with water of ash, when this medicine is not available to you. Take the ash from grapevine wood or ash from holm oak wood and throw it into the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Then filter it and administer it as an enema until you are confident that the bladder has been cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 If the patient cannot tolerate the Egyptian medicine or ash water, then administer it as an enema with water and honey to which some ground cinnamon has already been mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or administer it as an enema with mixed honey and wine, because it is the nature of honey to cleanse and wash, and wine makes the bladder adhere, especially when there is a preponderance of dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 When you do this several times and are confident that the bladder's corruption has been removed, then administer it as an enema with something that promotes the growth of flesh within it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 And this is done by taking diaphoretic plaster and dissolving it with rose oil and astringent wine, or by administering it as an enema with certain other medicines and ointments whose properties I have written about in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 If the opening of the bladder is too narrow for an enema to pass through, then slightly widen it with iron: or place a linen cloth wrapped in Egyptian ointment or in basil ointment within it until it widens.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And similarly, if the opening is also large, then sew together its lips with a stitch: and leave from it the amount into which an enema can enter without anything added.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly, if the opening from which the pus runs is raised upwards, then cut into it in a lower place that is within it, so that the pus may run out downwards; for when the pus is constricted in the depth of the Sinus, it prevents the growth of flesh in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 And if it is not possible for you to cut the Sinus lower down as you wish, then try to prepare the member with a preparation that will cause the pus to run out easily according to how it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 Try that nothing at all of the pus is retained in it; and take consolidative medicines which are placed on the mark, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 And spread them out onto a piece of linen.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 And let the piece of linen be large enough to cover the entire Sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then cut with scissors a hole directly into the opening of the Sinus, slightly larger than the opening of the Sinus itself.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then spread a soft ointment onto another piece of linen according to the size of the hole; and place it over the opening, positioned far from the Sinus opening, so that the exit of the pus may be relieved; and do not remove the large cloth until after some days, once a day.  />
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 But the one that is over the opening of the Sinus, that is the one you remove in every hour, so that what collects in it from the pus may go out; and so that you may know if that which runs out of it is much or little, or well digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 And with this again consider the place of the Sinus itself, whether its owner feels pain in it, or there is no pain in it, and whether there is a swelling in it, or there is no swelling in it.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 When your treatment is thus extended and you see the material coming out of the sinus opening, then know that the sinus has already attached or is approaching attachment; therefore, in the morning or on the third day, loosen it. And when you open the wound, change to another cloth and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 But if after a long time a fine pus comes out of the sinus, do not despair of its attachment, for its healing is approaching; for there are people who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and others act contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	 But if after many days undigested pus comes out of the sinus, then know that the sinus is not attached.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 If the attachment of the sinus is delayed and its condition prolonged, then in the treatment of the wound, let the medicines be made so that they are humid in substance but dry in power; such as the ointment dyafinicon, when to it is added an excess of zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 And one of the most effective treatments is to take the ointment dyafinicon and dissolve it in rose oil, and sprinkle over it an equal amount of old wine by substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 Then mix it together and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 Similarly, perform this action when you do not have the ointment dyafinicon present; instead use honey, cooked until it thickens, and use that.  />
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 Or take myrrh, aloe, and frankincense; grind all of it together, and sprinkle the powder over honey while it is on the fire.  />  />  />  />
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 Then place it on a cloth and bind it over the sinus; and when you have cooked the honey until it thickens, sprinkle over it spices and place another cloth over it, and bind that.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 And sometimes it is administered with long Aristolochia, and the root of heavenly lily, which is a lily; and herb flour, and Centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 Use them either as simples or in compound form; grind them and sieve the powder. Sprinkle it on the honey I mentioned, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 But if the sinus is prolonged and not healed by this treatment, then know that there is corruption deep within it; either it has already made an impression on the bones or on other hard parts of the body or ligaments. Then treat it with the treatment for fistulas as was stated before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 ¶ On the care of paronychia and broken nails, and on cutting into a finger and dissection.
Caput XCI.	 Chapter XCI
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 Paronychia is an abscess that occurs under the nail of the thumb of the hand or foot; and perhaps it may occur on the other fingers as well.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 When its duration is prolonged and the care of it neglected, it becomes an abscess with hot pus; or it corrupts and emits pus until it corrodes the root of the nail; and perhaps it corrupts it all, and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone until there is a foul odor. The tip of the finger becomes swollen and its color darkens. ︎
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 Therefore, when you treat it with what we have said in the section on division, and your treatment does not help, then you must cut off with a knife all the remaining overgrowth from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 For indeed, cautery is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 But if the bone is healthy and the nail is also healthy, and the overgrowths of the nail now press into the flesh on the inside and begin to prick it and injure it, then you must place a thin wire under the corner of the nail that pricks the flesh and push it up; and cut through the flesh with ease and apply to it what remains of medicines from burning, corrosive ones until all of it is removed. ︎
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 If the rottenness has already taken hold of the wound, then it is necessary that you cut out the wound and remove it; for it will never heal while a putrefied part remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 But if you see the ulcer and rottenness progressing into a finger, then cut it at one of its joints, as was mentioned earlier.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 But if the nail is injured by scraping or blows, and it causes intense pain, then you should first bleed the patient.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 Then cut the nail with a sharp pointed spoon, making an incision from top to bottom as far as you can see.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 And be careful that the incision does not reach the flesh underneath the nail, for you will cause intense pain to the patient, and it will become a cause of unnecessary growth of flesh in the place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 Then care for the place with something that soothes pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 But an additional finger that is born in the hands of some people is sometimes entirely fleshy; and sometimes there are bones in them, and sometimes there is a nail; and some of them are born at the root of the joint, or its growth is at certain joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 Therefore, that which is born at certain joints of the finger does not move; and that which is born at the root of the joint perhaps moves.  \\
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 Therefore, for those of them that are fleshy, its incision is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 That is, you should cut it at its root with a broad spoon.  />
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 But for those whose growth is at the root of the joint, its treatment is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 Therefore, refrain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 But for those born at the very tip of the finger, you should first cut its flesh with a round incision until it reaches bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 Then saw the bone with one of those saws suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 The union that occurs between fingers can often happen either from birth, that is, it is born with it, or from the healing of a wound, or from a burn by fire and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 Therefore, one should separate that union until the fingers return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Then put between them linens or cloths soaked in rose oil, so that they do not quickly heal together, and separate them; or put between them a thin lead sheet until the place heals as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly, if the union occurs between certain fingers and the palm, then cut that union according to how it is prepared and suitable for the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 ¶ About the Incision of a Fistula
Caput XCII.	 Chapter 92
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 A fistula is a twisted vein, swollen and full of black bile that occurs in many parts of the body; most commonly it happens in the legs, especially in the legs of travelers and workers who carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 Therefore, you should administer a strong purgative to expel black bile from the body several times.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Then perform phlebotomy on the patient, drawing blood from the basilic vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 Their treatment with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 One of them is that they should be cut and the black blood drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 And the other method is that the vein should be raised and removed entirely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 Its cutting is done in this manner:
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 First, bathe the leg with very warm water until the thick and foul blood is loosened. 》
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Then bind the patient's leg from its upper part near the hip to below the knee with a bandage. 》 》 》 》 》
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three with a broad incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then elevate, that is, draw blood from the lower part of the leg upwards with the hand, and the phlebotomist should first bleed the patient.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then cut the nail along with it downwards until an amount of blood comes out that you see is sufficient and which the strength of the patient can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Then tie it off and advise him to abstain from foods that produce black bile, and repeat the evacuation and bleeding when the veins fill up and cause harm to the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 Its elevation is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 Scrape the leg of the patient if it has many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then place him in a bath or wrap his leg with hot water until it becomes red and the veins swell up, or have him exercise strongly if there is no bath available until the limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then cut the skin along the course of the vein lengthwise or at its lower end near the knee or at the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then open the skin with hooks and strip the vein from all sides until it becomes visible to the touch, and at its appearance you will see it reddish towards black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 When it emerges from the skin, you will see it white as if it were a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then insert under it a probe until when it is elevated and comes out of the skin; hang it with a blunt hook gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then cut another incision near that incision by three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then strip the skin from the upper part of the vein until it becomes visible.  />
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then elevate it with probes as you did before, and hang it with another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 Then cut another section, or multiple sections if you need it.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then lift and cut the last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 Then draw it out to the section above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 And do this until you have drawn it out of the upper or all sections; when it has completely emerged, then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 But if it does not obey you in being drawn out and lifted, then insert a needle with a double thread, tie it off, and draw it out; or insert a probe beneath it, and turn your hand to every part until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And be careful that it is not cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 For if it is cut, it will be very difficult for you to lift it up, and harm will come to the patient from this.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, when you have drawn it all out, then place on the wound a wool cloth soaked in wine and rose oil or oil; and care for him until he is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 But if the grape is twisted and has a tortuous course with turns and is not as we said straight, then you should make incisions over it at every point of its tortuosity and at the places of its turns.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 Then suspend it with hooks until you have lifted it all up; and be careful in your section over it not to cut a vein or cause injury, for it will become difficult for you to lift up or draw out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 Therefore, keep your caution.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 The form of the incident which heals the grape.
Forma Vncini caeci.	 The form of the blind knot.  ?>
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 It does not have a curve like the other knots, nor is it sharp at the tip so as not to injure a vein; and it has a thick tortuosity, gentle, for if it were thin, it would cut the vein with its fineness; indeed, let there be an excess thickness in it, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 "On the Extraction of a Vein from the Leg.
Caput XCIII.	 Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as Alizegi and Arab lands, and in dry, hot lands where few tender plants grow, that is, where neither grass nor tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 Its generation is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, just as happens with internal worms and roundworms, and the worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 And the sign of the beginning of this vein's formation is that a severe inflammation occurs in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then the area becomes blistered.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then the vein begins to emerge from that blistered place, like a root of a plant or an animal.  \\
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 Therefore, when its end appears, then you should wrap a piece of lead over it, weighing from one drachm keil to two drachms and a nida (unit of weight), and let the suspended lead hang down from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 Whenever something comes out of it to the exterior, wrap that in lead and bind it.  •
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 But if it is greatly elongated, then cut off a part of it and wrap up the rest.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 And do not cut it at its root until it has all come out.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 For if you cut it, it contracts and enters the flesh; and causes an abscess and rotting in that place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore, it is necessary that it be gently handled and extracted little by little, until it has come out from its end, and nothing of it remains in the body; and from this vein comes out in some people what is in its length five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And now it has happened to me, because a man has left with twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 But if it should happen to you during your treatment: then insert a probe into its opening and perforate it through with a long opening, along with the body, until all that is in it from matter is expelled; and apply putrefaction of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then treat him according to the method for apostemes (abscesses).
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the ankle or on the foot itself; and many openings occur to it, and from each opening a branch emerges.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore treat it as we said in the division, and with what was mentioned before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 ¶ About cutting for worms generated under the skin, which is called "bouina" (ox-disease).
Caput XCIIII.	 Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This disease is called in a certain land among us "ox-disease," because it often happens to oxen; and there is one small worm that is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 And it travels throughout the whole body, ascending and descending; and it becomes evident to the senses during its movement from member to member, until it breaks out somewhere on the skin and emerges.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 Just as there are also worms and snakes, that is, earthworms and roundworms, in the intestines.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 And it should be feared because of its harmful nature.  /> It is a very serious disease.  /> When someone is afflicted with this disease, he must be treated according to the following method.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 Because when it travels through the body and is lifted up to the head and reaches that place, then perhaps it opens there and emerges and destroys the eye; and this happens very often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 Therefore when you want to cure him and extract it, then this cannot be done except during its movement and appearance to the senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 Therefore, you should tie what is above him and what is below him with a strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above him and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 If he sinks into the flesh and you do not find him, then place a cautery with fire on that spot until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 And what is to be feared most is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 But if you see that he has already reached the head near the eye, then tie a good ligature above him on the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above him and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 And the sick person should use cleansing of his body with medicines that dissolve bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 And let him beware of foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 On the incision for the disease called Nakir.
Caput XCV.	 Chapter 95
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This disease is called Nakir in our land, and it is a pain that occurs in certain members; then it changes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And indeed I myself have already seen this, as I narrate to you. >
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 And she exposed her arm, and I saw a small swelling on the vein of the forearm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And after I stayed there for one hour, I saw a swelling advance with heat, as if advancing like a worm, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than is possible; it was like living silver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 Therefore the pain withdrew from that place and settled in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 Then I stayed there for one hour, and it ran through the rest of the body until it reached the other arm. >
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Then she told me that it would turn around in her whole body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 I have observed the speed of its transition from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 And indeed before that, I had not seen this disease in my eyes as such.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 However, I have seen many who find the pain changing from limb to limb; and I did not see it myself as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 And I do not think that this is the case except because she was one of those who are from dry bodies with detectable veins; hence it appears to the senses that this wind has changed.  />  Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quia mulier erat ex illis qui sunt de uillis corporum sicci detegitarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui ea uentositas permutata.  />  And I do not think that this is the case except because she was one of those who are from dry bodies with detectable veins; hence it appears to the senses that this wind has changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reasoning in those who are delicate and of moist bodies with hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 Therefore, when you wish to cure it and the patient feels that pain, then if it is visible to your eye as we have said, quickly string above it and below it; and cut above it until that wind, constricted, comes out; and cauterize the place.  />
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 If however you do not see it with your eyes, then treat it with purging the body, and with that which expels winds, and drive them out with foul-smelling pills, and with pills of celery, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 ¶ On the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	 Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 Arrows are distinguished according to their kinds and according to the places into which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 Their variety is such that among them are those which have large points and small ones; and hollow ones and blunt ones.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And among these are those which have three corners.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And among them there are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And among them there are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 But those which fall according to the members are of two kinds.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 Or the members are from the main hollow organs, such as the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidney, intestine, bladder, and similar things.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 Therefore, when a missile falls into any of these members and the signs of death, which I will tell you about afterwards, appear to you, then it is necessary for you to extract that missile from them, because death follows him in whom it is, in many cases.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And when these bad signs do not appear to you and the missile is not hidden deep in the member, then extract it and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 For the signs of the brain when a missile falls into it and penetrates the nose and exits through the fontanel that is above the brain are: because severe convulsions, blindness, vertigo, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasms, confusion of mind, and vomiting of bile occur.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 And sometimes blood comes out of the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 And sometimes speech is cut off and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And from the place of the wound comes out a white liquid like gruel.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And from it comes something like the moisture of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If therefore these signs appear to you, then abstain from treating it, and extract the missile if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The signs of a missile when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left nipple; and he feels with it as if it were fixed in something hard, not in something hollow. 》
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps the arrow has a motion similar to that of the pulse, and black blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 And it is followed by coldness in the extremities, cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Know therefore that death has certainly descended.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 And the sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung is that frothy blood flows from the wound, and the vessels following the neck become inflamed, and the color of the patient changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And he exhales a large, deep breath, and seeks cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If the arrow falls into the diaphragm, which is in the chest, then it is near the small ribs; and there is a great panting with severe pain and sighing, and all the limbs of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out of the wound with the food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 And if the arrow falls into the belly and is fixed there, then something of feces comes out of the wound, or a little piece of gut or an already torn intestine.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 There is therefore no hope for his cure, nor for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 But if the arrow falls into the bladder and urine comes out, and something protrudes to the outside, and the pain is stronger on the patient, then know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The other members, such as the face, neck, throat, shoulders, arms, ribs of the back, clavicle, hip, leg, and similar from the limbs are cured in many ways, provided that the arrow does not find an artery or nerve, and the arrow is not poisoned.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you what I have seen of these arrows, so that you may know it for your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 Which is, that a certain man had an arrow fall into the lacrimal of his eye, at the root of the nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 I removed it from her on the other side, under the fat of her ear; and she was healed, and nothing happened to her eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 And I removed another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen into the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I obtained nothing from it except a small part of its end, to which its wood adhered; and it was a large arrow from the bows of the Turks, with a soft iron, in which there are no barbs.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 Therefore, the Jew was healed, and nothing evil happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I removed another arrow from a Christian's throat.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 And it was an Arabic arrow, and that one has barbs.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 Therefore, I cut above it between the two windpipes; and it was already sunk into his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 Therefore, I was careful with it until I removed it; and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 And I removed another arrow from a man who had it fall into his abdomen; and we thought that he would die from it.  ?>
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After thirty days had passed and nothing of his condition had changed, I cut above the arrow; and I split it open, and I removed it; and he was healed, and no evil befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man into whose back an arrow had fallen, and the wound above it had healed over.  ?>
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After seven years had passed, the arrow came out at the base of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 And I saw a woman into whose abdomen an arrow had fallen, and the wound above it had healed over, and the arrow remained inside her; and nothing of her condition changed, and the woman did not find any harm in any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 And I saw another man whose arrow fell into his face; and the wound healed, leaving a little pain, and many similar cases like these.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 And I extracted an arrow from a man of the king's nobles, which had fallen into the middle of his nose and then turned slightly towards the right side; and the entire arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 Therefore I was called to treat him after the incident with the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 I found therefore that the wound of the arrow was very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 Therefore I examined it with a fine probe and did not feel it; but he himself found the puncture and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 Therefore I hoped that this was the puncture from the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 Therefore I applied a plaster to the place with attracting and digestive power, hoping that the place would swell up and show me the sign of the arrow so that I could cut above it; and no incident occurred in the place indicating that the arrow had reached there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 Therefore I continued with the plaster on him for many days; and no incident occurred, and the wound healed meanwhile; but he remained weak from its extraction for several days until one day he felt the arrow inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 Therefore I placed an acute, corrosive medicine on this wound for many days until it opened up; and when I probed it with a probe, I felt the fine tip of the arrow attached to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Then I added to the opening of the wound with this acute medicine until the tip of the arrow appeared to us visibly; and about four months passed with him.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 Then after the wound had increased and it was possible for me to introduce tweezers into it and move it, but it did not obey to come out; then I did not cease refining and contriving over it with various devices until one day I began on it with well-made tweezers, according to the form that will appear at the end of this chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 Then I repaired the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And indeed doctors judge that the nasal cartilage cannot be restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 Therefore I repaired it [the nasal cartilage], and the wound became consolidated, and the patient was healed with complete health; nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I tell you the quality of the extraction of certain arrows, so that you may take it as a rule and example for what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended with narration, nor does the book comprehend it; and a wise craftsman compares little to much, and what is present to what is absent; and he finds a new operation and a new instrument for descending into foreign matters of this art when they occur.  (Here, "foreign" refers to things outside of the usual scope of the art.)
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 I say therefore that arrows do not come out of the members in which they are fixed except by two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Or by pulling from the place into which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or by the contrary action on the other part [of the arrow].
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And that which comes out from where it entered is either an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place and is pulled out;
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 But if it does not come out at the time of its fall, then you must leave it for a few days until the flesh around it begins to putrefy; and its pulling out is relieved, and its removal becomes easier.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 And similarly, if it is fixed in bone and does not come out to you at the time of its fall, then leave it also for a few days; and tug on it with attraction and movement every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 But if it does not come out to you after the days, then you must pierce around the arrow in the very bone from every side with a fine drill until the arrowhead becomes enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then pull it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 But if an arrow is stuck in the bone of the head and has already penetrated one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those symptoms I mentioned appear on the patient: then refrain from pulling out the arrow and leave it there until its condition becomes balanced after several days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 For if an arrow reaches the sphenoid bone, then death is not delayed for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 And if the arrow is not lodged except in the body of the bone only and does not penetrate to the sphenoid, and the patient remains for several days and nothing of those symptoms occurs to him: then endeavor to pull out the arrow and extract it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 But if it is very firmly lodged and does not yield to your efforts at extraction: then apply treacle around the arrow, as I have told you; then treat the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 But if the arrow has already hidden itself within the body and is concealed and hidden from sensation: then seek it with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 If you feel it, then pull it out with some instruments that are suitable for its extraction.  />
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 If you cannot reach it because of the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow deep within: and there is no bone, or nerve, or vein there: then make an incision over it until the wound is enlarged and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 But if there are ears on which it is lodged, then free the flesh fixed in them from every side, by any means you can do that, and endeavor, if it cannot be extracted because of the fracture of the ears and their contortion, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 And you, when you administer the extraction of an arrow, wherever it is, then use the twisting of your hand with pincers to all parts, until you make it come out: and be very careful not to break the arrow and make its attraction and extraction difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot remove it in one hour, then leave it for some days until what is around it putrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then reopen it; for the skin will be relieved. But if bleeding opposes you, then administer what we said in its treatment in its own chapter; and protect your virtue from cutting a vein, or nerve, or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And administer the remedy in every way possible for avoidance of a dart; and let it be with ease, and calmness, or slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 And it is necessary that when you draw the dart, the patient should be weak according to the figure as it was in the case of the dart itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 But if that is not possible for you, then administer what is possible from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 But if the dart emerges from the opposite side of the other part, or if something already protrudes to the exterior; or if the tip of the dart causes a prominence by touch on the nearby upper skin surface, and you see it standing out: cut over it, and let the incision be according to the quantity that forceps can grasp in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then draw it; for it becomes easy for exiting.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 But if it is retained in the bone, then turn your hand according to the roundness, until the dart imprints on the bone and enlarges itself; then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not: leave it for some days; then reopen it until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 But if the dart has a wooden shaft, then push it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 But if the wooden shaft has fallen off and you want to administer a push: then insert into it a hollow instrument, so that its concavity enters into the tail of the dart; then push it out with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If however the arrow is barbed, then push it through with an instrument that enters into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 For the arrow will be relieved by this.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 But if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut out all the flesh in which the poison is found; if you are able to do this.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then treat it with what is suitable for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 But if the arrow has fallen into the chest, or the belly, or the bladder, or the side; and it is close to what you touch with a probe, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and beware of cutting a vein or nerve, and remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 Then, whether the wound, if you see [it], treat that until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 And this is the form of the forceps with which arrows are removed.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 Let the ends be similar to the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp over an arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 And many forms are made from them, large and small and medium-sized, according to the size of the arrow and its narrowness, and the width of the wound and its tightness.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 The form of a barbed pusher.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 And the form of a blunt pusher.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is the end of a blunt instrument like a radius, so that its entry into a barbed arrow may be relieved, and it may be pushed along with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The end of a barbed pusher is barbed like the feather of a bird, so that the entry of the arrow into it and its pushing may be relieved.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 ¶ On bleeding veins.
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 The veins that are customarily bled are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 Of which sixteen are in the head: two pulsating veins that are behind the ears, called the two herbs; and two arteries that appear in the two temples; and two veins that are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, which are called "the observers"; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is at the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 And two Guidicei, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 And these are the veins called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 The veins which are used for bloodletting in the arms are five in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 One of them is called the Cephalic and it comes from the outer side; and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	 And the Dark Vein.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 And it is the Median vein, and it consists of a branch of the Basilic and a branch of the Cephalic; and the common people call it the body vein. ()));
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 And the Basilic, which is located on the inner side, and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 And the common people call it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 And the Funis brachii, which is located above the elbow; and this is the one used for bloodletting, and it is clearly visible above the thumb.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 And Saluatella: and this is a vein which is between the ring finger and little finger; and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 And in the leg and foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 One of them is located under the thumb's nail on the outer side. ))) 1037
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 And the second is called the Saphenous, and its location is near the heel on the inner side. ))) 1040 ))) 1056 ))) 1072
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 And the vein called Nesse, and its location is near the heel on the outer side.
